[[Ernst von Salomon]] | based on = {{based on|''[[08/15 (novel)|08/15]]''|[[Hans Hellmut Kirst]]}} | starring = | music = [[Rolf A. Wilhelm]] | cinematography = [[Heinz Hölscher]] | editing = [[Walter Boos]]
[[Arnfried Heyne]] | studio = Divina-Film | distributor = Gloria Filmverleih AG | released = | runtime = | country = West Germany | language = German | budget = | gross = }} '''''08/15''''' is a 1954–55 West German film trilogy directed by [[Paul May]] and based on the novel ''08/15'' by [[Hans Hellmut Kirst]] who also served as the film's screenwriter (published in English as "The Revolt of Gunner Asch"). The term ''08/15'' (nill-eight/fifteen, {{lang-de|Null-Acht/Fünfzehn}}) refers to the German Army's standard machine gun, the 08/15 (or [[MG 08|MG 08 model 15]]), by far, the most common German machine gun deployed in [[World War I]]. It was manufactured in such large quantities that it became the German Army slang for anything that was standard issue. The film follows the story of Private Asch, a German soldier in [[World War II]]. The film title implies that Asch, and the soldiers under his command, were unostentatious (i.e. "run-of-the-mill") characters deployed on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]].Bartov, Omer (2004). "Celluloid Soldiers: Cinematic Images of the Wehrmacht". In Ljubica & Mark Erickson. ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy.'' London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. {{ISBN|0-297-84913-1}}. ==Premise== The last of the ''08/15'' film trilogy ends with Germany being occupied by American soldiers who are portrayed as bubble-gum chewing, slack-jawed, uncultured louts, inferior in every respect to the heroic German soldiers. The only exception is the Jewish emigrant, now a US officer, who is shown as both intelligent and unscrupulous, the fact interpreted by Professor [[Omer Bartov]] as implying that the "real tragedy of World War II was that the Nazis did not get a chance to exterminate all Semites, who have now returned with Germany's defeat to once more exploit the German people". "Although Asch is never identified with the Americans – indeed, in the final film of the trilogy, the Americans appear to be nearly as dangerous a foe as the ''[[SS]]''."''Screening War: Perspectives on German Suffering'', page 26. ==Parts== * [[08/15 (1954 film)|Part 1: ''In der Kaserne'' (''In the Barracks'')]] * Part 2: ''Im Krieg'' (''In War'') * Part 3: ''In der Heimat'' (''Back Home'') ==Cast== *[[Joachim Fuchsberger]] as Private I Class / Staff Sergeant / Lieutenant Asch *[[Helen Vita]] as Lore Schulz * [[Peter Carsten]] as [[Corporal]] Kowalski ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book | last=Kapczynski | first=Jennifer M. | chapter=Armchair Warriors: Heroic Postures in the West German War Film | year=2010 | editor1-last=Cooke | editor1-first=Paul | editor2-last=Silberman | editor2-first=Marc | title=Screening War: Perspectives on German Suffering | series=Screen Cultures: German Film and the Visual | isbn=1-57113-437-9 | pages=23–27 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m1MdufwL9QgC&lpg=PP1&dq=isbn%3A1571134379&pg=PA26#v=onepage&q&f=false }} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0046671|08/15}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:08 15 (film series)}} [[Category:Film series introduced in 1954]] [[Category:German-language films]] [[Category:West German films]] [[Category:World War II films]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Films based on German novels]] [[Category:Films based on military novels]] [[Category:Films directed by Paul May]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} Fictional depictions of the [[4th millennium]] AD (3001-4000 AD) have appeared across nearly all media.
==Film and television== ===Film=== * In ''[[South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut]]'', according to the song "[[What Would Brian Boitano Do?]]", "When Brian Boitano traveled through time to the year 3010/He fought the evil robot king/to save the human race again." * In the movie ''[[Titan A.E.]]'', the Earth is destroyed in the year 3028; the rest of the movie takes place in 3043-44. * The [[stop-motion]] film ''[[Live Freaky! Die Freaky!]]'' is set in 3069. * The film ''[[Planet of the Apes (1968 film)|Planet of the Apes]]'' is set in the year 3978, while its first sequel ''[[Beneath the Planet of the Apes]]'' is set in the year 3955. At the conclusion of ''Beneath''..., a [[cobalt bomb]] detonation incinerates the Earth. It is possible that the first film occurs in an [[Alternate history|alternate timeline]] to the subsequent four. The next three films, ''[[Escape from the Planet of the Apes]]'', ''[[Conquest of the Planet of the Apes]]'' and ''[[Battle for the Planet of the Apes]]'' each refer to this timeline for [[Cornelius (Planet of the Apes)|Cornelius]] and [[Zira (Planet of the Apes)|Zira]].
===Live action TV=== * The ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'' episode "[[Living Witness]]" takes places in the latter half of the 31st century, approximately [[24th century|700 years after the rest of the series]]. * In ''[[Star Trek: Enterprise]]'', one of the factions involved in the [[Temporal Cold War]] is from the 31st century. In the episode "[[Shockwave (Star Trek: Enterprise)|Shockwave]]", Captain [[Jonathan Archer]] is briefly transported to the 31st century in an alternate timeline in which the [[United Federation of Planets]] was never established. According to ''Enterprise'', [[time travel]] has become a commonly used method of exploration by this point. * In the TV show ''[[Planet of the Apes (TV series)|Planet of the Apes]]'', the ship's chronometer indicates that the astronauts are marooned on a future Earth on or after March 21, 3085. According to the TV show, another ship crash-landed on Earth 10 years prior. * The January 3262 sequence of the ''[[Babylon 5]]'' episode "[[The Deconstruction of Falling Stars]]" depicts a devastated Earth which has regressed to a medieval level of technology as a result of a nuclear war called "the Great Burn" [[28th century|500 years earlier]]. The planet was in the process of rebuilding itself with the clandestine assistance of the [[Ranger (Babylon 5)|Rangers]]. * In ''[[The Outer Limits (1963 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]'' episode "[[Soldier (The Outer Limits)|Soldier]]", the eponymous Qarlo Clobregnny, as played by [[Michael Ansara]], originates from the 38th Century and is thrown back in time to 1964. * In the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' serials ''[[Mission to the Unknown]]'' and ''[[The Daleks' Master Plan]]'', the [[Dalek]]s conspire to conquer the [[Solar System]] in the year 4000. * In the ''Doctor Who'' episode "[[Cold Blood (Doctor Who)|Cold Blood]]", the Doctor sets the Silurian alarm system to wake them up after one thousand years, aka 3020. * The ''Doctor Who'' episode "[[Sleep No More (Doctor Who)|Sleep No More]]" takes place in the 38th century.
===Animated TV=== * The TV show ''[[Futurama]]'' mainly takes place in the early years of the 31st century (3001–3013). In this series, the head of [[Richard Nixon's head|Richard M. Nixon]] wins the 3000 planetary election and becomes [[president]] of [[Earth]]. The episode ''[[Decision 3012]]'' concerns a president sent back from the year 3028. * The TV show ''[[Rocket Robin Hood]]'' takes place in 3001 and follows the adventures of [[Robin Hood]]'s descendant Rocket Robin Hood and the rest of the Merry Men who travel on the mobile, rocket-powered Sherwood Asteroid. * In the ''[[Courage the Cowardly Dog]]'' episode, "1000 Years of Courage", a space rock hits the [[farmhouse]] and sends Eustace, Muriel, and Courage into the year 3001, when the human race has evolved into living bananas. * In ''[[The Simpsons]] episode'', "[[The Father, the Son, and the Holy Guest Star]]", the ending is set in 3005, a thousand years after the episode was first broadcast in 2005. * The Japanese-French cartoon series ''[[Ulysses 31]]'' transposes the events of ''[[The Odyssey]]'' to the 31st century. * In the animated series ''[[Megas XLR]]'', MEGAS, the prototype battle unit from the future, and its previous owner, Kiva, are from the 31st century. * The [[Cartoon Hangover]] series ''[[Bravest Warriors]]'', created by [[Pendleton Ward]], takes place some time around 3085. It could be possible that Ward's other series ''[[Adventure Time]]'' takes place around that time because it is set a thousand years [[Apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction|after a nuclear war]] (referred to as 'The Great Mushroom War'), in the land of Ooo, in which magic is rediscovered and humans are nearly wiped out, with only few remaining, and all kinds of creatures having taken their place. * On the cartoon ''[[Lazer Tag Academy]]'', Jamie Jaryn travels to 1987 from 3010 to save her ancestors from Draxon Dreer. * In the ''[[South Park]]'' episode "[[Goobacks]]", the time machine is invented in 3045 and people travel to the present to work. * Both the [[Sonic the Hedgehog (comics)|''Sonic the Hedgehog'' comic book]] and [[Sonic the Hedgehog (SatAM)|its Saturday morning cartoon]] in the [[United States]] take place in the 33rd Century. * [[Bucky O'Hare]] lives and operates in the 33rd century. * In the [[CatDog]] episode "CatDog 3001", CatDog travels in time to the year 3001, and Winslow becomes an evil gigantic big tyrant of Nearburg. * In the [[Challenge of the Superfriends]] episode ''Conquerors of the Future'', the [[Legion of Doom (Super Friends)|Legion of Doom]] travels forward in time from the 20th century to the year 3984. Humans here are embroiled in a battle with creatures based on [[Morlocks]] called Barlocks, who the Legion forms an alliance with. * Most of the ''[[Legion of Super Heroes (TV series)|Legion of Super Heroes]]'' animated TV series takes place on the 31st century. * In ''[[The Impossibles (TV series)|The Impossibles]]'', Dr. Futuro is from the 40th century. * The events in the cartoon series ''[[Thundarr the Barbarian]]'' take place in the year 3994, 2,000 years after a runaway planet hurtled "between the Earth and the Moon, unleashing cosmic destruction." * The anime ''[[From the New World (novel)#Anime|From the New World]]'', Based on ''[[Yusuke Kishi]]'''s novel of the same name primarily takes place in the early 31st century.
==Comics==
===Western=== * In the [[Marvel Universe]], the [[Guardians of the Galaxy (1969 team)|original Guardians of the Galaxy]], the sorcerer [[Sise-Neg]], and the villain [[Kang the Conqueror]] are all from the 31st century. * [[DC Comics]]' ''[[Legion of Super-Heroes]]'' titles are set 1000 years after "the present day", meaning that more recent stories are set in the 31st century. * In [[Planet Comics]], in the Lost World section the Earth has been invaded in the 33rd century by the Voltamen. * The comic series [[Ramayan 3392 A.D.]] is set in the year 3392. * The [[Justice League|JLA]] villain the [[Lord of Time]] is from the year 3786. * In [[Marvel Comics]], [[Cable (comics)|Nathan Christopher Summers]] is transported to the 40th century by the [[Askani]] to aid them in their battle against [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]], who has conquered Earth. This possible future timeline is designated as Earth-4935. * The year 4000 is the time for the classic comic book ''[[Magnus, Robot Fighter]]'' created by [[Russ Manning]]. In this series, all of North America has become a single great city named North Am, with buildings commonly reaching a mile (1.6 km) in height.
===Manga=== * In the [[manga]] and [[anime]] series ''[[Bobobo-bo Bo-bobo]]'' the series takes place in the year 300X (Three thousand X) though in the American version of the anime it's 3001.5. * In the [[manga]] [[Book series|series]] ''[[Biomega (manga)|Biomega]]'' by [[Tsutomu Nihei]], 3005 is the year when the story begins with humans successfully landing on [[Mars]]. * [[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga)|Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind]] is set 1000 years after the "Seven Days of fire", which took place within the 2750s in the 28th century (1000 years after the beginning of the [[Industrial Revolution]]). This means, Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind takes place anywhere within the 3750s in the 38th Century. * The Japanese [[manga]] and [[anime]] series ''[[Trinity Blood]]'' takes place in an indeterminate time in the future, 900 years after an apocalyptic war between all of Earth's nations destroyed civilization, when humanity has reestablished itself ([[armageddon]]), in the half of the 31st century. * In [[Sailor Moon]], the protagonist's daughter, Chibiusa, is from the 31st century.
===Webcomics=== * The web comic [[Starslip]] takes place in the 35th century. * The [[Webcomic]] ''[[Schlock Mercenary]]'' is set solely in the early 31st century, presumably beginning in the year 3000 and progressing to the current year of 3006.
==Literature== * ''[[3001: The Final Odyssey]]'', the final novel in [[Arthur C. Clarke|Arthur C. Clarke's]] ''[[Space Odyssey]]'' series takes place in 3001. * Most of [[Isaac Asimov]]'s [[Robot series (Asimov)|''Robot'' series]] takes place in the second half of the fourth millennium. * The year 3053 marks the beginning of the events in the science fiction novel ''[[Rainbow Mars]]'' by [[Larry Niven]]. * The beginning of the novel ''[[Venus on the Half-Shell]]'' is set in 3069. * [[Samuel R. Delany]]'s novel ''[[Nova (novel)|Nova]]'' is set in the 32nd century. * The second book of [[A Canticle for Leibowitz]] by [[Walter M. Miller, Jr.]], "Fiat Lux" (Latin: Let There Be Light), is set in a late medieval post-apocalyptic former United States, which has rediscovered [[electricity]], and is undergoing political consolidation. [[Saint Leibowitz and the Wild Horse Woman]] is set in c3274, one century after the events of "Fiat Lux". It deals with disunity within the post-apocalyptic [[Roman Catholic Church]], pagan barbarian incursions and the consolidation of the "Empire of Texarkana" in the former southwestern United States. In the year 3781 ("Fiat Voluntas Tua"), a second [[nuclear holocaust]] destroys all life on Earth. However, survivors escape to human [[interstellar colony|interstellar colonies]]. * The events of Dan Genesis's novel ''Awakening [Beginnings Pt. I]'' take place over the summer of 3215. The events of the second novel, ''Ignition, [Beginnings Pt. II]'', take place over the remainder of the year. * [[Nelson S. Bond]]'s short story "Magic City" begins on June 14, 3485. * [[Kirth Gersen]], hero of the [[Demon Princes]] novels by [[Jack Vance]] is born in the 35th century. In 3524, the beginning of ''[[Star King]]'', he comes to Smade's Planet. * 3596: The novel series ''[[Legend of the Galactic Heroes]]'' begins. * ''[[The Songs of Distant Earth]]'' by [[Arthur C. Clarke]] is mostly set in the 39th century. * In [[David Weber]]'s [[Honorverse]], the family of [[Honor Harrington]] comes to the [[Star Kingdom of Manticore]] and settles on the planet Sphinx in 3620. Harrington is born in 3961. * [[Nostradamus]]' final alleged prophecy places the definitive [[Apocalypse|end of the world]] in 3797. <ref>[https://www.biography.com/news/nostradamus-predictions "Nostradamus Predictions", December 11, 2017. Retrieved on March 28, 2018.]</ref>
==Music== * "Preludio para el año 3001" is a tango by [[Ástor Piazzolla]] with lyrics by [[Horacio Ferrer]]. * The 1998 [[music video]] "Victory" by [[Puff Daddy]] (and featuring [[Notorious B.I.G.]] & [[Busta Rhymes]]) takes place in 3002 and follows the adventures of a 'runner' from the '[[New World Order (conspiracy)|New World Order]]'. * [[Scars on Broadway]] released a song named 3005 on their debut album entitled ''[[Scars on Broadway (album)|Scars on Broadway]]''. * "You'll never survive 3005" as said in the song ''3005'' by ''[[Scars On Broadway]]''. * The [[Widespread Panic]] song "Don't Tell the Band" sets the apocalypse at the year 3010. * In [[The Black Eyed Peas]] song "Boom Boom Pow" has a line where [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]] says "I'm so 3008, you so 2000-late." * The [[Justin Bieber]] song "[[Beauty and a Beat]]" has a line that says: "We're gonna party like it's 3012 tonight". * The [[Saturday Night Live]] and [[The Lonely Island]] song "Space Olympics" in set in the year 3022. * [[Del tha Funkee Homosapien]], [[Dan the Automator]], and [[Kid Koala]] produced the [[High concept|high-concept]] hip-hop album ''[[Deltron 3030 (album)|Deltron 3030]]'', a story of corporate destruction and love lost in a post-apocalyptic 31st-century universe. * The song "[[In the Year 2525]]" by [[Zager and Evans]] predicts that by the year 3535, thoughts and actions are going to be controlled by pills. * In "[[3005 (song)|3005]]" by Childish Gambino, he states, "Fuck these other Niggas, I'll be right by your side, till 3005"
==Games== * The great majority of the events of the [[BattleTech|Classic ''BattleTech'']] timeline occur in the 31st century. * [[Horizon Zero Dawn]] is in the early-to-mid 31st century. The protagonist, Aloy, is born on [[April 4]]th, 3021 with the main story being set in the year 3040. * ''Galactic Champions'', a far-future setting for the [[Champion]]s superhero role-playing game from [[Hero Games]] using the [[Hero System]], is set in the early 31st century. * The roleplaying game [[Artix Entertainment|Mechquest]] by Artix Entertainment is set from years 3007-3010 AD, and continuing as time advances. * The events of the ''[[MechWarrior: Dark Age]]'' expansion to ''[[BattleTech]]'''s timeline occur in the 32nd century, following the collapse of the [[BattleTech technology#Hyperpulse generators|HPG]] network in 3132. * The video game [[Elite: Dangerous]], the fourth game in the Elite series, takes place in the 3300s. * 3587: The year in which both the [[iPhone]] space-shooter game ''Galaxy on Fire'' and the [[Multiplayer online battle arena|battle arena]] game ''[[Awesomenauts]]'' take place. * The [[Supreme Commander (video game)|''Supreme Commander'']] video game series takes place between the years 3764 to 3844. the Infinite War itself raged for one thousand years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forums.gaspowered.com/viewtopic.php?f%3D25%26t%3D40915 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=October 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022044724/http://forums.gaspowered.com/viewtopic.php?f=25&t=40915 |archivedate=October 22, 2013 }}</ref> * ''[[Tribes 2]]'', while mainly set in 3941, its training missions take place from 3944 to 3950. * When calculating the year in the game with the beginning of NC, in the game ''[[EV Nova]]'', the year is 3955 (It could be possible that the date of the game was influenced by the ''[[Planet of the Apes (1968 film)|Planet of the Apes]]'' film series). *A space trading and combat named ''Endless Sky'' takes place in 3013.

{{italic title}} [[File:L'Adoration des bergers, 1633, Londres, National Gallery.jpg|thumb|300px|''The Adoration of the Shepherds'', 1633–34, by [[Nicolas Poussin]]]] [[File:L'Adoration des bergers, 1633, Londres, National Gallery (cropped3).jpg|thumb|Detail with the ''[[Annunciation to the Shepherds]]'' in the distance]] [[File:L'Adoration des mages, 1633, Dresde, Gemäldegalerie.jpg|thumb|Poussin's ''The Adoration of the Magi'', dated 1633, Dresden]] [[File:Le Jeune Pyrrhus sauvé Poussin Musée du Louvre.jpg|thumb|Poussin's ''The Saving of the Infant Pyrrhus'', by 1634 [[Louvre]], another "coppery" colour scheme. <ref>Wine, 338</ref>]] [[File:L'Adoration des bergers, 1633, Londres, National Gallery (cropped).jpg|thumb|Detail with [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]], [[Jesus]], [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]], the ox and ass]] <!-- British English, and NO infobox please --> The '''''Adoration of the Shepherds''''' is a painting of 1633–34 by the French painter [[Nicolas Poussin]] (1594–1665), now in the [[National Gallery, London]] (Room 19). It is in [[oil painting|oils]] on canvas, and measures {{convert|97.2 x 74| cm}} (with uneven edges). Unusually for Poussin, it is signed "N. Pusin.fe" ["[[fecit]]"] on the stone at lower right.<ref>Wine, 334</ref> By 1637, soon after it was painted, it was owned by Cardinal [[Gian Carlo de' Medici]] (1611{{ndash}}1663),<ref>Wine, 334</ref> the second son of [[Cosimo II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Grand Duke Cosimo II of Tuscany]] and was placed in his villa outside [[Florence]].<ref>Wine, 334</ref>
It belongs to a group of paintings with a predominately "coppery" colour scheme, from which its dating mainly derives. Classicising elements have been added to the usual figures.<ref>Wine, 337–339</ref>
The painting was evidently well-regarded, and 20 painted copies are recorded from approximately the next century, as well as seven [[old master print|print]] versions made between the 1660s and 1813.<ref>Wine, 334–336</ref> There are a number of drawings, some showing what appear to be early thoughts about the composition, though some may not be by Poussin or were created before the painting.<ref>Wine, 334–339</ref> As is often the case with Poussin, elements of the painting reflect the works of other artists, including [[Raphael]].<ref>Wine, 337–338</ref>
==Description == To the usual cast of the [[Nativity of Jesus in art]] are added the earlier scene of the [[Annunciation to the Shepherds]] in the distance at the centre, five ''[[putti]]'' above, about to shower the scene with flowers, and a woman at left holding a large [[wicker]] tray with fruit. The scene takes place in a large but derelict classical building, to which a crude wooden lean-to stable has been added. The golden stone of the building is echoed by the tanned bodies of the shepherds, the cloudy sky, and other elements, giving an unusually unified "coppery" colour scheme to the painting, with the blue of the [[Virgin Mary]]'s mantle and that of the woman carrying the fruit the other prominent colour. The ox, to the right of [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]], almost disappears into the wall behind him.<ref>Wine, 338</ref>
Unlike those in the still central scene, the figures in the small background Annunciation to the Shepherds are highly agitated, with extreme and strenuous poses. The gesturing angel is loosely painted in white against the cloud, just above the foremost vine leaves in the basket. Like other figures by Poussin from this period, the foreground figures seem to have a frozen sculptural quality.<ref>Blunt, 162</ref> The figure with a green dress is female. The foremost kneeling shepherd is close to, and perhaps derived from, a shepherd in a painting of the Nativity by [[Raphael]] ([[Vatican Loggie]]).<ref>Wine, 338–339</ref>
==Date== Other paintings by Poussin, generally dated to the years between 1633 and 1634, have similar colour schemes. The ''Adoration of the Magi'' in the [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister]] in [[Dresden]] (illustrated) is dated 1633; it has a very similar setting but a more varied colour scheme, so the London ''Adoration of the Shepherds'' is assumed to be later than that. The ''Saving of the Infant Pyrrhus'' in the [[Louvre]], with a similar unified "coppery" scheme, has now been shown to have been finished by 1634 at the latest, so the London painting is now assigned to 1633–34 with reference to these, and also a drawing with a preparatory sketch on the [[verso]], now in the [[Royal Collection]]. This was made for Marshall [[Charles III de Créquy]] when he was French ambassador to Rome, resident there between June 1633 and July 1634.<ref>Wine, 338–339</ref>
Another "coppery-toned" National Gallery Possin (in 2015 hanging next to this one) is ''[[The Adoration of the Golden Calf]]'', also dated 1633–34, largely on the basis of this similarity.<ref>Wine, 320</ref> This is usually thought to have been painted as a pair with ''[[The Crossing of the Red Sea (Poussin)|The Crossing of the Red Sea]]'', now [[National Gallery of Victoria]], [[Melbourne]]; the two remained together until 1945.<ref>Wine, 314, 319–320</ref>
==Background== The painting was done when Poussin was approaching the age of 40. He had been in Rome since 1624, and enjoyed some success in the 1620s, in particular when his main patrons were not abroad on embassies. These were Cardinal [[Francesco Barberini (1597–1679)|Francesco Barberini]] (1597–1679), nephew of the current Pope, [[Urban VIII]] (reigned 1623–1644), and his secretary, the [[antiquarian]] [[Cassiano dal Pozzo]] (1588–1657), who was to remain an important friend and patron of Poussin. However, when in 1628 Barberini secured him the commission for an [[altarpiece]] in [[St. Peter's Basilica|St Peter's]], the ''Martyrdom of St Erasmus'' ([[Pinacoteca Vaticana]]), its reception seems to have been lukewarm, which perhaps triggered a change in Poussin's career, along with a period of illness in 1629 or 1630.<ref>Blunt, 159–160; Mahon, 16–40 and throughout; Wine, 276</ref>
At this time he seems to have abandoned the pursuit of the many rich commissions Rome offered for large paintings for churches and palaces, and henceforth painted only canvases of a relatively small size for "a small circle of ''[[Connoisseur|cognoscenti]]''",<ref>Blunt, 160</ref> led by dal Pozzo. That this painting quickly passed to a Medici prince-cardinal makes it rather untypical for this period, though during the 1630s awareness of Poussin's talent was growing in the French court, until he was eventually ordered by the king to return to Paris in 1640 (he escaped back to Rome two years later, and never left again).<ref>Blunt, 163–165</ref>
His style and subject-matter also changed at the end of the 1620s, switching away from the influence of [[Italian Baroque art|Italian baroque]] painters to a classicism influenced by [[classical sculpture]] and the [[High Renaissance]]. His paintings from about 1629 to 1633 are nearly all drawn from [[classical mythology]], or the epics of [[Torquato Tasso|Tasso]]. The Dresden ''Adoration'', dated 1633, perhaps marks the end of this phase, and for the rest of the 1630s his subjects become once again more varied.<ref>Blunt, 160–163</ref>
==Iconography== [[File:L'Adoration des bergers, 1633, Londres, National Gallery (cropped5).jpg|thumb|Detail of the ''[[putti]]'']] Nativity scenes are very often given such classical settings. As well as showing off the artist's skill and learning they acted as a reminder of the medieval legend, reported in the popular compilation of the ''[[Golden Legend]]'', that on the night of Christ's birth the [[Basilica of Maxentius]] in Rome, supposed to house a statue of [[Romulus]], had partly tumbled to the ground, leaving the impressive ruins that survive today.<ref>[[Christopher Lloyd|Lloyd, Christopher]], ''The Queen's Pictures, Royal Collectors through the centuries'', p.226, National Gallery Publications, 1991, {{ISBN|0-947645-89-6}}. In fact the Basilica was not built until the 4th century. Some later painters used the remains as a basis for their depictions.</ref>
Another meaning for the ruined temple went back to 15th-century [[Early Netherlandish painting]], when the usual simple shed of the Nativity stable, little changed from [[Late Antiquity]], had developed into an elaborate ruined temple, initially [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] in style, which represented the dilapidated state of the [[Covenant (biblical)|Old Covenant]] of the [[Jewish law]].<ref>Schiller, pp. 49–50. Purtle, Carol J, "Van Eyck's Washington 'Annunciation': narrative time and metaphoric tradition", p.4 and notes 9–14, ''Art Bulletin'', March, 1999. Page references are to online version. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0422/is_1_81/ai_54517312 online text]. Also see [http://www.tau.ac.il/arts/projects/PUB/assaph-art/assaph2/articles_assaph2/09Pinson.pdf ''The Iconography of the Temple in Northern Renaissance Art'' by Yona Pinson] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326170616/http://www.tau.ac.il/arts/projects/PUB/assaph-art/assaph2/articles_assaph2/09Pinson.pdf |date=2009-03-26 }}</ref> In Italian works the architecture of such temples became classical, reflecting the growing interest in the ancient world, and the ruins that remained in many areas.<ref>Schiller:91-82</ref>
The woman with the fruit can be paralleled in some other paintings, and if the work was actually commissioned by Cardinal de' Medici, a reference to a statue of ''Plenty'' by [[Donatello]], now lost but then prominently displayed in the Mercato Vecchio of his home-city of Florence, may have been intended. It was also a Florentine custom to bring gifts of fruit to women after childbirth, no doubt to be placed on their ''[[desco da parto]]''.<ref>Wine, 338</ref> Various meanings might be attached to both the apples and grapes the woman appears to carry, and the types of flowers held by the ''putti'', though other than the [[jasmine]] held by the top left ''putto'', the identification of these is not entirely clear.<ref>Wine, 338</ref>
The main surviving preparatory drawing is in the [[British Museum]]. This is in a horizontal format, just showing the lower part, and may suggest that Poussin originally intended a smaller painting with a horizontal format, although the drawing is cut along its top edge. This includes an upturned [[pediment]] stone at bottom left, a low arch in the centre at what is now about halfway up the final composition, and a lamb lying below Jesus. [[Christ Church Picture Gallery]] in [[Oxford]] has a drawing with the ''putti'', again with differences in the architectural background.<ref>Wine, 339</ref>
==Provenance== The painting was still in the collection of Cardinal Gian Carlo de' Medici in a posthumous inventory in 1663, after which it may have moved to France, where a ''Nativity'' attributed to Poussin is recorded in a number of collections for the next century. These include that of [[Louis Phélypeaux (1643-1727)|Louis II Phélypeaux]] (1643–1727), better known as the chancellor de Pontchartrain, an important French politician.<ref>His jobs included: [[Secretary of State of the Navy (France)]], [[Secretary of State of the Maison du Roi]], [[Controller-General of Finances]], [[Chancellor of France]]</ref> [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]] noted seeing such a painting in his collection in 1665,<ref>Wine, 334</ref> and one is recorded in his wife's collection in 1672. Another mention, from 1700, is in the collection of [[André Le Nôtre]] (1613–1700), the landscape architect and principal gardener of King [[Louis XIV of France]],<ref>Wine, 334</ref> and there are two further owners of what was probably the same painting, ending in a posthumous sale in 1761.<ref>Wine, 334 and notes</ref>
At this point it may have passed to England; in 1795 what was certainly the same painting was in the posthumous sale of Sir [[Joshua Reynolds]]' collection at [[Christie's]],<ref>Wine, 334</ref> where it fetched 205 guineas.<ref>Wine, 334</ref> It was bought by the painter and dealer [[Henry Walton (English painter)|Henry Walton]] who sold it a year later to Sir Thomas Beauchamp-Proctor, 2nd Baronet (1756–1827).<ref>Wine, 334</ref> It remained in the collections of the [[Proctor-Beauchamp baronets]] and their family between 1796 and 1956, when it fetched £29,000 at [[Sotheby's]], bought by an overseas collector. An export licence was deferred, allowing the National Gallery to buy the work for £33,100 in 1957, with funds from the Temple-West Fund, the [[The Art Fund|NACF]], and a special Treasury grant. It is catalogued as NG 6277.<ref>Wine, 334</ref>
==Condition== The condition is "generally good ... but with some wear". There are some minor [[pentimenti]] and retouches. As of 2001, the painting was last "cleaned and restored" in 1958, then "surface cleaned and revarnished" in 1975.<ref>Wine, 336</ref>
==Exhibitions== Apart from National Gallery exhibitions since 1957, it has travelled to the [[Royal Academy]] in 1880 and 1995, [[Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery]] 1992–93 and Paris in 1994–95 ([[Grand Palais]]).<ref>Wine, 334</ref>
==See also== * [[Adoration of the Shepherds (Le Nain)|''Adoration of the Shepherds'']], another French painting, c. 1640 by the [[Le Nain brothers]], also in the National Gallery

{{Infobox scientist | name = Alexander Veselovsky | image = Alexander Veselovsky.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1838|02|04}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1906|10|10|1838|02|04}} | death_place = [[Saint Petersburg]] | residence = [[Russian Empire]] | field = [[Philology]], [[History]] | work_institution = <!-- {{Moscow University Professor|1}} --> | alma_mater = {{Moscow University|1895}} | education = [[Doctor of Science]] <small>(1872)</small> | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = [[Fyodor Buslaev]] | doctoral_students = | prizes = }} '''Alexander Nikolayevich Veselovsky''' ({{lang-ru|Алекса́ндр Никола́евич Весело́вский}}) ({{OldStyleDate|February 16|1838|February 4}} in [[Moscow]] – {{OldStyleDate|October 23|1906|October 10}} in [[St. Petersburg]]) was a leading [[Russian Empire|Russian]] literary theorist who laid the groundwork for [[comparative literature|comparative literary studies]].
== Life and work ==
A general's son, Veselovsky studied privately with [[Fyodor Buslaev]] and attended the [[Moscow University]] from 1854 to 1858. After a brief stint in [[Spain]] as a tutor to the Russian ambassador's son, Veselovsky continued his education with [[Heymann Steinthal]] in [[Berlin]] and [[Prague]] and spent three years working in the libraries of [[Italy]]. Upon his return to Russia, he delivered lectures in Moscow and St. Petersburg and was elected a Member of the [[St. Petersburg Academy of Sciences]] in 1876.
Veselovsky's early studies of medieval [[Italian literature]] led him to believe that many plots and literary devices were imported to Europe from the [[Orient]] through [[Byzantium]]. Looking at literature primarily from a genetic point of view, Alexander Veselovsky and his brother [[Aleksey Veselovsky|Aleksey]] (1843-1918) attempted to construct a comprehensive theory of the origin and development of poetry. In 1899, the elder brother famously argued that "the font and syncretic root of poetic genres" may be traced to ritualized popular games and folk incantations.<ref>[[Eleazar Meletinsky]]. ''The Poetics of Myth''. Routledge, 1998. Page 139.</ref>
== Influence ==
In the [[Soviet Union]], Veselovsky and his followers were criticized for their "ethnographism", which allowed "source study to grow to a hypertrophied degree, thus dissolving the specific character of the literary work into a collection of ''influences''".<ref>Rachel Polonsky (''English Literature and the Russian Aesthetic Renaissance''. Cambridge University Press, 1998. Page 17) quoting: Jauss, Hans Robert. ''Toward an Aesthetic of Reception.'' University of Minnesota Press, 1982.</ref> On 14 August 1946 the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party]] adopted a resolution specifically condemning "kowtowing" to the bourgeois West by the so-called Veselovskyists.<ref>[[Mikhail Bakhtin]], ''Rabelais and His World''. Indiana University Press, 1984. Page XX.</ref> The [[Russian Formalists]] largely shared a critical view of Veselovsky's theory, although it has been suggested that Veselovsky's doctrine was actually a point from which they evolved "in a linear, if polemical, way".<ref>Dragan Kujundzic. ''The Returns of History: Russian Nietzscheans After Modernity''. SUNY Press, 1997. Page 8.</ref>
Although his work has been largely forgotten by Western scholarship (probably due to lack of translations), Veselovsky has been called "one of the most erudite and original scholars Russia has produced"<ref>''Gogol from the Twentieth Century: Eleven Essays'', ed. Robert A. Maguire. Princeton University Press, 1974. Pages 39-40.</ref> and "the most remarkable representative of comparative literary study in Russian and European scholarship of the nineteenth century".<ref>Rachel Polonsky (''English Literature and the Russian Aesthetic Renaissance''. Cambridge University Press, 1998. Page 17) quoting [[Viktor Zhirmunsky|Zhirmunsky]]'s ''Sravnitelnoe literaturovedenie'', p. 84.</ref>

'''Allophilia''' is having a positive attitude towards outgroup members. The outgroup members can be anyone who possesses characteristics that are different from one's own, such as people of different [[Race (human categorization)|races]], [[religion]]s, [[culture]]s, etc. It is a framework for understanding effective intergroup leadership and is conceptualized as a measurable state of mind with tangible consequences.<ref>{{cite news|title= Allophilia—a new framework for understanding effective intergroup leadership|author= Todd Pittinsky|url= http://www.centerforpublicleadership.org/?option=com_content&task=emailform&id=267&itemid=2|newspaper= [[Center for Public Leadership]], [[Harvard Kennedy School]]|date= |accessdate= 18 June 2013|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130620034033/http://www.centerforpublicleadership.org/?option=com_content&task=emailform&id=267&itemid=2|archivedate= 20 June 2013|df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Positive prejudice: Really loving your neighbour |author= |url= http://www.economist.com/node/8859092 |newspaper= [[The Economist]]|date= 15 March 2007 |accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref>
The term "allophilia" was coined by [[Harvard]] professor Todd L. Pittinsky in 2006, after he was unable to find an antonym for prejudice in any dictionary.<ref>{{cite news |title=Otherly Love: The Law of Dissimilars|author= Ashley Pettus|url= http://harvardmagazine.com/2006/01/the-law-of-dissimilars.html|newspaper= [[Harvard Magazine]] |date=January 2006 |accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref> The term derived from [[Greek language|Greek]] words meaning "liking or love of the other".<ref>Pittinsky, T. L. (2010). A two-dimensional theory of intergroup leadership: The case of national diversity. American Psychologist, 65(3), 194-200.</ref>
Allophilia has five statistical factors: # affection, # comfort, # engagement, # enthusiasm, # kinship.
The Allophilia Scale measures each of these factors.<ref>{{cite news |title=Allophilia: Beyond tolerance lies true respect|author= Sheema Khan|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/allophilia-beyond-tolerance-lies-true-respect/article9130024/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] |date=28 February 2013 |accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref><ref>Pittinsky, T. L., Rosenthal, S. A., & Montoya, R. M. (2010). Measuring positive attitudes toward outgroups: Development and Validation of the Allophilia Scale. In L. Tropp & R. Mallett (Eds.), Beyond Prejudice Reduction: Pathways to Positive Intergroup Relations. Washington, D. C.: American Psychological Association.</ref> It has been adapted and validated to other languages such as Italian and Spanish, also to various settings, such as to measure positive attitude toward people with dementia, younger and older adults.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alfieri|first=S.|last2=Marta|first2=E.|date=2011|title=Positive attitudes toward the outgroup: adaptation and validation of the Allophilia scale|url=|format=|journal=Testing, Psychometrics, Methodology in Applied Psychology|volume=18|pages=99–116|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morales|first=J. F.|last2=Magallares|first2=A.|date=2017|title=Psychometric properties, factorial structure and construct validity of the Spanish version of the Allophilia Scale|url=|journal=Anales de Psicologia|volume=33|pages=283–291|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kinney|first=J. M.|last2=Yamashita|first2=T.|last3=Brown|first3=J. S.|date=2016|title=Measuring positive attitudes toward persons with dementia: A validation of the Allophilia scale|url=|journal=Dementia|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wagner|first=L. S. |last2=Luger|first2=T. M. |date=2017|title=Assessing positive attitudes toward older and younger adults|url=|journal=Educational Gerontology|volume=43 |issue=3|pages=143–165|via=}}</ref> [[File:Allophilia Scale.svg|thumb|right|340px|Allophilia scale]]
'''Allophilia, Prejudice, and Positive Intergroup Relations'''
The typical remedy for [[prejudice]] is to bring conflicting groups into a state of tolerance. However, tolerance is not the logical antithesis of prejudice, but rather is the midpoint between negative feelings and positive feelings toward others. Allophilia enhancement should serve as complement to prejudice reduction.<ref name="ref3">Pittinsky, T. L., & Montoya, R. M. (2009). Symhedonia in intergroup relations: The relationship of empathic joy to prejudice and allophilia. Psicologia Sociale, 3, 347–364.</ref><ref>Pittinsky, T. L. (2009). Allophilia: Moving beyond tolerance in the classroom. Childhood Education, 85(4), 212–215.</ref><ref>Pittinsky, T. L. (2009). Look both ways. Phi Delta Kappan, 90(5), 363–364.</ref>
Allophilia predicts positive relationships with outgroup members. For instance, a study in Spain shows that students having higher allophilia had lower social distance toward people with obesity.<ref>Magallares, A. (2017). Predictors of Social Distance Toward People with Obesity: The Role of Allophilia. International Review of Social Psychology, 30(1).</ref> Besides, positive experience with outgroup members may increase allophilia, as it is shown in a longitudinal study of a cook's tour in Vietnam. In that study, the participants, who were Americans, reported positive feelings toward Vietnamese mirroring Allophilia facets in nearly 10 years after the event.<ref>Livert, D. (2016). A Cook's Tour Abroad: Long‐Term Effects of Intergroup Contact on Positive Outgroup Attitudes. Journal of Social Issues, 72(3), 524-547.</ref>
In one study, [[mudita|symhedonia]] (experiencing empathic joy) has been shown to be more closely associated with allophilia, while sympathy (experiencing empathic sorrow) has been shown to be more strongly associated with prejudice.<ref name="ref3"/>

'''Barbara Rose, Ph.D''' (born 1938) is an American [[art historian]] and [[art critic]]. She was educated at [[Smith College]], [[Barnard College]] and [[Columbia University]], where she studied under [[Meyer Schapiro]]. She also studied at [[New York University Institute of Fine Arts]] with Walter W.S. Cook. Through [[Michael Chapman (cinematographer)]], Rose was introduced to many New York artists, including [[Carl Andre]] and [[Frank Stella]]. In 1961, Rose received a Fulbright to Spain. Stella joined her in Europe and the two were married in 1961 in London. They divorced in 1969.{{cite web |work=Dictionary of Art Historians |title=Barbara Rose |publisher= |last=Sorenson |first=Lee |url=https://dictionaryofarthistorians.org/roseb.htm |accessdate=2015-07-31 |date=November 27, 2000}} With the encouragement of [[Michael Fried]] Rose began writing art criticism, which, in 1963, led to a monthly "New York Letter" in [[Art International]]. In October 1965, Rose published the essay '''ABC Art''' in [[Art in America]], in which she described the fundamental characteristics of [[minimal art]]. ==ABC Art== In her essay, ''ABC Art'', Rose considers the diverse roots of [[minimalism]] in the work of [[Kasimir Malevich]] and [[Marcel Duchamp]] as well as the choreography of [[Merce Cunningham]], the art criticism of [[Clement Greenberg|Greenberg]], the philosophy of [[Wittgenstein]] and the novels of [[Robbe-Grillet]]. In examining the historical roots of [[minimal art]] in 1960s America, Rose draws a distinction between [[Malevich]]'s "search for the transcendental, universal, absolute" and [[Duchamp]]'s "blanket denial of the existence of absolute values." Rose grouped some 1960s artists as closer to [[Malevich]], some as closer to [[Duchamp]], and some as between the two. Closer to Malevich are [[Walter Darby Bannard]], [[Larry Zox]], Robert Huot, [[Lyman Kipp]], [[Richard Tuttle]], Jan Evans, Ronald Bladen, [[Anne Truitt]]. Closer to Duchamp are [[Richard Artschwager]] and [[Andy Warhol]]. Between Malevich and Duchamp she places [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], [[Donald Judd]], [[Carl Andre]], and [[Dan Flavin]]. Her conclusion is that [[minimal art]] is both [[transcendence (religion)|transcendental]] and negative:
"The art I have been talking about is obviously a negative art of denial and renunciation. Such protracted asceticism is normally the activity of contemplatives or mystics...Like the mystic, in their work these artists deny the ego and the individual personality, seeking to evoke, it would seem, the semihypnotic state of blank unconsciousness."
She also contrasts [[minimal art]] with [[Pop Art]]:
"...if Pop Art is the reflection of our environment, perhaps the art I have been describing is its antidote, even if it is a hard one to swallow."
==Career== From 1962 until 1965, Rose was a New York correspondent for Art International; a contributing editor at [[Art in America]] from 1965 through 1971; at [[Vogue (magazine)]] from 1966 until 1988; and at [[Artforum]] from 1965 until 1973. From 1970 until 1971, Rose served as the first director of the museum at the [[University of California, Irvine]]. She was also an art critic for [[New York (magazine)]] from 1971 until 1977, art editor at the [[Partisan Review]] from 1975 until 1996, associate editor at Arts magazine from 1978 until 1988, and editor-in-chief of the "Journal of Art" from 1988 through 1991. Rose served as a consultant to [[Condé Nast]] from 1970 until 1987 and to the GSA Art in Architecture program from 1990 to 1992. From 1981 until 1985, Rose held the position of senior curator at the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Houston]] where she curated shows including "Miró in America" in 1982 and " Fernand Léger and the Modern Spirit: An Avant-Garde Alternative to Non-Objective Art," also in 1982. The [[College Art Association]] of America awarded Rose the Distinguished Art Criticism Award in 1966 and 1969. Rose's books include "American Art Since 1900" (1967); "The Golden Age of Dutch Painting" (1969); "Lee Krasner" (1983); and "Autocritique: Essays on Art and Anti-Art" (1989). She has also published countless catalogue essays, produced eight films, and curated museum exhibitions. Rose was the senior curator at the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Houston]] from 1981 and 1985 and the founding director of the [[Katzen Arts Center]] at [[American University]]. Rose is also credited with popularizing the term [[Neo-Dada]]. ==Bibliography== *Barbara Rose, ''ABC Art,'' ''[[Art in America]]'', October 1965 *Barbara Rose, ''American Art Since 1900'', 1967 *Barbara Rose, ''Abstract Illusionism'', [[Artforum]], October 1967, pp. 33–37. *Barbara Rose, [[Billy Klüver]], J. Martin (eds). Pavilion: [[Experiments in Art and Technology]]. New York: E. P. Dutton, 1972 ==See also== * ''[[North Star: Mark di Suvero]]'' (1977) is a documentary film about [[Mark di Suvero]] that was produced by Rose and filmmaker François de Menil; the film's musical score was composed and recorded by Rose's friend, [[Philip Glass]]. * [[Neo-Dada]] * [[Abstract illusionism]] * [[Experiments in Art and Technology]] * [[Minimal art]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://archives2.getty.edu:8082/xtf/view?docId=ead/930100/930100.xml;query=;brand=default Barbara Rose papers] at the Getty Research Institute. A '''beach fale''' is a simple thatched hut in [[Samoa]]. Beach fales are also common in other parts of [[Polynesia]]. They have become popular in [[tourism]] as a low budget accommodation situated by the coast, built with a few posts, no walls and a thatched roof with a round or oval shape.
The word ''fale'' (pronounced fah-leh) is the Samoan word for any type of building. A similar word is used in other [[Polynesian language]]s, similar to [[whare]] in the [[Maori language]].
In [[Architecture of Samoa|Samoan architecture]], these simple huts are called ''faleo'o'' in the [[Samoan language]]. They are common in villages where they provide extra storage or space for [[dragon boat]]s.
As the term denotes, beach fale are usually located around the coast in villages. In Samoa, renting out a beach fale to visitors is a common means for providing extra income for families.<ref>Samoa Tourism Authority, {{cite web |url=http://www.visitsamoa.ws/samoa/cms/accom/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227053123/http://www.visitsamoa.ws/samoa/cms/accom/ |archivedate=2007-12-27 |df= }} How Stuff Works, http://travel.howstuffworks.com/american-samoa-national-park-ga2.htm</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery class="center" widths=150px heights=150px> File:Fale on Manono Island.jpg|beach fale on [[Manono Island]] File:Beach fale interior - Samoa 2009.jpg|Interior of a beach fale File:Beach fale Samoa 2009.jpg File:Samoa Savaii Falealupo Beach1.JPG|Looking out from a beach fale File:Falealupo Beach Fale Accommodation, Savai'i, Samoa, Polynesia.JPG|Beach fale [[Falealupo]], [[Savai'i]] island </gallery>
==Fale tele== [[File:Samoan fale, Lelepa village, Savaii, Samoa 2009.JPG|thumb|160px|''Fale tele'', [[Lelepa (village)|Lelepa]] village, [[Savai'i|Savai'i Island]]]] In comparison to beach fale, this is a large traditional Samoan house, ''fale tele'' which serves as a meeting house or guest house.

Being '''bedridden''' is a form of immobility that can present as the inability to move or even sit upright.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bedridden|title=Definition of BEDRIDDEN|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-14}}</ref> It differs from bed-rest, a form of non-invasive treatment that is usually part of recovery or the limitation of activities. Some of the more serious consequences of being bedridden is the high risk of developing [[Thrombosis prevention|thrombosis]] and [[Muscle atrophy|muscle wasting]] (atrophy). Its meaning is derived from a middle English term (bedrid) from a 1300s past tense form of riding a bed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/bedridden|title=The definition of bedridden|last=|first=|date=|website=Dictionary.com|access-date=2018-02-14}}</ref>
== Bed rest == {{Main|Bed rest}} This is a voluntary [[medicine|medical]] treatment still used today to help cure illness.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Dictionary of Medical Terms|last=Collin|first=|publisher=A&C Black|year=2008|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=Credo Reference}}</ref> Current views regarding this treatment are that there are no benefits for most conditions studied.<ref name="Lancet1999">{{cite journal|last1=Allen|first1=C|last2=Glasziou|first2=P|last3=Del Mar|first3=C|title=Bed rest: a potentially harmful treatment needing more careful evaluation.|journal=Lancet|date=9 October 1999|volume=354|issue=9186|pages=1229–33|pmid=10520630|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(98)10063-6}}</ref> Though bedrest may still be prescribed for pregnant women, it is now considered dangerous.<ref>[http://www.webmd.com/baby/guide/bed-rest-during-pregnancy Bed Rest During Pregnancy<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="Lancet1999" /><ref>[http://commonhealth.wbur.org/2013/05/unethical-bed-rest-for-pregnant-women Is It 'Unethical’ To Prescribe Bed Rest For Pregnant Women? | CommonHealth<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>http://arms.evidence.nhs.uk/resources/qipp/664578/attachment</ref> Those who are bedridden can develop complications related to feeding.
== Complications == Being bedridden leads to many complications such as loss of muscle strength and endurance. Contractures, osteoporosis from disuse and the degeneration of joints can occur. Being confined to bed can add to the likelihood of developing an increased heart rate, decreased cardiac output, hypotension, and thromboembolism.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maclin|first=V. M.|last2=Radwanska|first2=E.|last3=Binor|first3=Z.|last4=Dmowski|first4=W. P.|date=August 1990|title=Progesterone:estradiol ratios at implantation in ongoing pregnancies, abortions, and nonconception cycles resulting from ovulation induction|journal=Fertility and Sterility|volume=54|issue=2|pages=238–244|issn=0015-0282|pmid=2379624}}</ref> People with disabilities who are bedridden are at risk for developing [[Pressure ulcer|pressure sores.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/disabilityandhealth/relatedconditions.html|title=Related Conditions {{!}} Disability and Health {{!}} NCBDDD {{!}} CDC|date=2018-02-06|work=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|access-date=2018-03-12|language=en-us}}{{PD-notice}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/bed-sores/symptoms-causes/syc-20355893|title=Bedsores (pressure ulcers) - Symptoms and causes|work=Mayo Clinic|access-date=2018-03-12|language=en}}</ref> Those who are bedridden are at risk in a house fire due to their lack of mobility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37674354/police-hawaii-recruiter-sexually-assaulted-boy-multiple-times-while-he-was-bedridden|title=Police: Woman who recruited exchange students to Hawaii raped one while he was bedridden|last=Kawano|first=Lynn|access-date=2018-03-12|language=en}}</ref> Showering can become impossible.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/mexican-man--once-the-world-s-fattest--dreams-of-walking-again-9983670|title=Mexican man, once the world's fattest, dreams of walking again|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2018-03-12|language=en-US}}</ref> Bedsores develop if a person: who spends most or all of the day in bed without changing position<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/003976.htm|title=Skin care and incontinence: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia|website=medlineplus.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-03-12}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> Being confined to bed may result in a person remaining passive and withdrawn. The ability to transfer to a chair and the negative attitudes of caregivers is associated with continued confinement to bed and reduction of such requests.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Forbes|first=Dorothy A.|date=2009-04-01|title=Being bedridden was a slow process influenced by interactions with the environment, nurses, and social tiesCommentary|url=http://ebn.bmj.com/content/12/2/64.1|journal=Evidence-Based Nursing|language=en|volume=12|issue=2|pages=64–64|doi=10.1136/ebn.12.2.64|issn=1367-6539|pmid=19321841}}</ref> Those who are confined to bed have risks related to falls. Falling from a bed can result in injury.
== Prevention == One recommendation for preventing the complications of being bedridden is to eat a healthy, well-balanced diet that contains enough calories and protein needed for optimum health. If someone is confined to bed changing position at least every two hours can help prevent complications in addition to change sheeting and bedclothes immediately if they are soiled, and using items that can help reduce pressure, such as pillows or foam padding.<ref name=":0" />
== Studies == One [[India]]n study of care given to bedridden individuals at home found that family members made up 82% of [[caregivers]]. A high rate of [[Complication (medicine)|medical complications]] was reported, including [[pressure ulcers]] and [[urinary tract infection]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Profile of home-based caregivers of bedridden patients in North India|url=http://ijcm.org.in/article.asp?issn=0970-0218;year=2011;volume=36;issue=2;spage=114;epage=119;aulast=Bains|author=Puneet Bains|author2=Amarjeet Singh Minhas|publisher=[[Indian Journal of Community Medicine]]|date=22 August 2011}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Carl F. Bucherer | logo = Carl F. Bucherer Logo.svg | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_name = | type = [[Aktiengesellschaft|AG]] | industry = Watch manufacturing | founded = 1888 | founder = Carl Friedrich Bucherer | hq_location = | hq_location_city = [[Lucerne]] | hq_location_country = [[Switzerland]] | area_served = | key_people = {{ublist |Sascha Moeri ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) |Jörg G. Bucherer ([[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]])}} | products = | brands = | services = | owner = | num_employees = 200 | website = {{URL|www.carl-f-bucherer.com}} }} '''Carl F. Bucherer''' is a Swiss ''[[Manufacture d'horlogerie|haute horlogerie]]'' company based in [[Lucerne]], [[Switzerland]], which manufactures luxury men's and women's mechanical watches. Since its founding in 1888, the company has been wholly owned by the Bucherer family, making Carl F. Bucherer one of the oldest luxury Swiss watchmakers continuously held by the founding family. The company is run by the original family's third generation, with Jörg G. Bucherer serving as chairman of the board.{{cite news |date= |title=Carl F. Bucherer: Tradition combined with innovative strength |url=http://www.watchoogle.com/tradition-combined-with-innovative-strength/ |agency=Watchoogle }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The watch models of Carl F. Bucherer can be distinguished by certain functions including the [[chronograph]], [[Flyback chronograph|flyback]], [[Tachymeter (watch)|tachymeter]], [[tourbillon]] as well as indicators and displays such as big date and day, power reserve, 24 hours, moon phases, three time zones, calendar, and [[perpetual calendar]].{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/swiss-watch-manufacturer |title=Swiss watch manufacturer |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer}} ==History== [[File:Carl Friedrich Bucherer Clockmaker.jpg|thumb|150px|Carl Friedrich Bucherer, founder of the Swiss watch manufacturer.]] In 1888, Carl Friedrich Bucherer established his first boutique selling watches and jewelry in Lucerne, Switzerland. In 1919, Carl Friedrich Bucherer launched his first ladies’ watch collection in the [[art deco]] style. He is one of the first watchmakers to adopt the watch strap, which at the time was still a revolutionary concept. By 1948, the company was focusing on sporty chronographs that prominently displayed the current date.{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/lucerne-1888 |title=Made of Lucerne Since 1888 |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} [[File:Carl F. Bucherer boutique.jpg|thumb|left|100px|Carl Friedrich Bucherer's first boutique in Lucerne, Switzerland.]] By 1968, Carl F. Bucherer had manufactured around 15,000 high-precision, certified [[chronometer watch|chronometers]], making the company one of the top three Swiss producers of these specialized timepieces. In 1969, the company became part of a Swiss consortium for the development and production of the first quartz [[Movement (clockwork)|movement]] for wristwatches, the Beta 21. In 1976, Jörg G. Bucherer, the third generation of the family, took over the company. In 2001, the Carl F. Bucherer brand was [[Positioning (marketing)|repositioned]] and the company launched the Patravi watch collection. In 2005, the company filed a patent for the monopusher mechanism of the Patravi TravelTec watch, which permits the parallel display of three time zones. In 2007, Carl F. Bucherer acquired Téchniques Horlogères Appliquées of [[Sainte-Croix, Switzerland]] and incorporated it into the company as Carl F. Bucherer Technologies. The acquisition enables the company to research, develop, and produce its own manufacture movements and modules for additional functions. This leads in the following year to the company's launch of the CFB A1000 manufacture movement, which features a peripheral motor.{{cite web |url=https://issuu.com/carlfbucherer/docs/cfb_collection_2014-2015_en |title=Collection 2014/15 |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} In 2014, the Manero PowerReserve becomes the first Carl F. Bucherer model to receive a unique laser signature in order to ensure product authenticity and quality.{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/news/manero-powerreserve-0 |title=Manero PowerReserve |date=16 May 2014 |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} From that year, all models are equipped with this technology.{{cite news |date=28 May 2014 |title=Fighting Replica Watches With Hidden Laser Images & Nanostructuring |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/arieladams/2014/05/28/fighting-replica-watches-with-hidden-laser-images-nanostructuring/ |newspaper=Forbes }} ==Production== [[File:Carl F. Bucherer Women's Wristwatch.jpg|thumb|The first Carl F. Bucherer ladies' wristwatch, from 1919.]] In order to increase its production capacity, Carl F. Bucherer moved its production workshops from [[Nidau]] to a larger production site in [[Lengnau, Bern]] in 2002.{{cite news |date=18 November 2004 |title=Carl F. Bucherer: Mit Personifizierung die Welt erobern |url=http://www.handelszeitung.ch/unternehmen/carl-f-bucherer-mit-personifizierung-die-welt-erobern |newspaper=HandelsZeitung }}{{cite web |url=http://www.fhs.ch/eng/2001-11-08_129.html |title=Carl F. Bucherer: From Nidau To Lengnau |date=8 November 2001 |publisher=Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry }} In 2015, Carl F. Bucherer announced that its manufacturing will be consolidated to a new factory in Lengnau in order to optimize production processes and its [[Value chain|value-added chain]], as well as increase the scope of [[Vertical integration|vertical manufacturing]].{{cite news |date=28 August 2015 |title=Carl F Bucherer - Établissement d'un centre de compétences à Lengnau |url= |newspaper=Journal de Sainte-Croix et environs }}{{cite news |date=4 July 2016 |title=Carl F. Bucherer: The new Manufacture in Lengnau is operational |url=http://en.worldtempus.com/article/industry-news/carl-f-bucherer-new-manufacture-lengnau-operational-2455219 |agency=WorldTempus }} The company currently sells about 25,000 watches a year (around 60% men, 40% women) .{{cite news |date=13 August 2015 |title=In Conversation With Sascha Moeri, CEO, Carl F. Bucherer |url=http://luxurysociety.com/articles/2015/08/in-conversation-with-sascha-moeri-ceo-carl-f-bucherer |agency=Luxury Society }} The price range varies between CHF 5,000 and CHF 30,000 with some exception over CHF 400,000. The world market is divided between Europe with 40%, Asia also 40% and rest of the world, including US market with 20%. http://www.cfb-communication.com Official Facts and Figures 2017 ==In-house manufacture movement== [[File:CFB A2000 Caliber Watch Movement.png|thumb|150px|left|The CFB A2000 caliber manufacture movement.]] The CFB A1000 caliber has the first reliably functioning, peripherally-mounted rotor, which is made of [[tungsten]]. The peripheral rotor provides power when turning in either direction and allows for full visual display of the movement. The A1000 movement includes the patented "Dynamic Shock Absorption" (DSA) system for effective shock absorption. [[File:Manero Peripheral.jpg|thumb|150px|The 2016 Manero Peripheral model, marking the launch of the CFB A2000 movement family.]] At [[BaselWorld]] 2016, Carl F. Bucherer introduced the CFB A2000 manufacture movement. The A2000 retains the A1000 caliber's signature winding mechanism but is enhanced from a 3[[Hertz|hz]] to a 4Hz beat rate "for increased precision and a newly free-sprung balance for increased resistance to shock-induced timing deviation." The A2000 has the [[COSC]] Swiss Chronometer certification to attest to its high-level performance.{{cite news |date=17 March 2016 |title=Carl F. Bucherer Introduces CFB A2000 |url=http://iwmagazine.com/news-and-now/20160317/carl-f-bucherer-introduces-cfb-a2000/ |newspaper=International Watch Magazine |access-date=2016-06-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919012715/http://iwmagazine.com/news-and-now/20160317/carl-f-bucherer-introduces-cfb-a2000/# |archive-date=2016-09-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Carl F. Bucherer's new Manero Peripheral model, also introduced at BaselWorld 2016, is driven by the CFB A2000-based CFB A2050 caliber. This watch marks the launch of the CFB A2000 movement family.{{cite news |date=23 March 2016 |title=BaselWorld 2016: Carl F. Bucherer A2000 |url=http://iwmagazine.com/news-and-now/20160323/baselworld-2016-carl-f-bucherer-a2000/ |newspaper=International Watch Magazine }}{{cite news |date=16 March 2016 |title=Carl F. Bucherer Manero Peripheral |url=http://en.worldtempus.com/article/new-watches/carl-f-bucherer-manero-peripheral-2453767 |agency=WorldTempus }}{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/manero-peripheral-00-10917-03-23-01 |title=Manero Peripheral |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer}} The new Manero Flyback model features the CFB 1970 caliber, "which is controlled by a gearwheel and also provides a flyback function, allowing multiple time intervals to be measured in quick succession."{{cite news |date=17 March 2016 |title=All Eyes On… Carl F. Bucherer: The Golden Move |url=http://www.europastar.com/magazine/cover-stories/1004088563-all-eyes-on-carl-f-bucherer-the-golden-move.html |newspaper=Europa Star }} ==Authentication== As of 2014, the company's manufacture movements have been protected against [[Counterfeit consumer goods|counterfeiting]] by special laser technology. Developed by the Swiss company Mimotec SA, the CLR-[[LIGA]] process imprints a unique signature on the surface of the watch movement using diffractive nano-structuring that can then only be authenticated with a specialized laser scanning device.{{cite web |url=http://www.mimotec.ch/anglais/Product/contrefa%C3%A7on.html |title=Say ''STOP'' to counterfeiting… |date= |publisher=Mimotec SA |access-date=2015-09-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930051836/http://www.mimotec.ch/anglais/Product/contrefa%C3%A7on.html# |archive-date=2015-09-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Models== Carl F. Bucherer watches are divided into five core collections:{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches |title=Collection |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} * Patravi.{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/patravi/ |title=Patravi |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }}{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/sport-watches-men-women/ |title=Sport Watches for Men and Women |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }}{{cite news |date=29 March 2005 |title=Kosmopolitisches für Weltreisende von Carl F. Bucherer |url=http://www.nzz.ch/articleCLJ49 |newspaper=Neue Zürcher Zeitung }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * Manero.{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/manero/ |title=Manero |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} * Adamavi (luxury watches).{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/adamavi/ |title=Adamavi |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} * Pathos (luxury watches for women).{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/pathos/ |title=Pathos |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} * Alacria (jewelry watches for women).{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/watches/alacria/ |title=Alacria |date= |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }}
File:Patravi ScubaTec Watch.jpg|The Patravi ScubaTec [[Diving watch|diver's watch]]. File:Manero Tourbillon Limited Edition Watch.jpg|The Manero Tourbillon Limited Edition. File:Manero PowerReserve Watch.jpg|The Manero PowerReserve. File:Pathos Desire.jpg|The Pathos Desire. File:Patravi TravelTec FourX.jpg|The Patravi TravelTec FourX Limited Edition ==125th anniversary== [[File:Patravi ScubaTec SFV Edition Watch.jpg|thumb|right|The Patravi ScubaTec SFV Special Edition.]] In 2013, Carl F. Bucherer celebrated its 125th anniversary with an international roadshow presenting over 200 historical watches and the history of the company. The company also released four limited edition watches: the Manero MoonPhase, Manero Tourbillon, Alacria RoyalRose, and the Patravi TravelTec FourX. A jubilee volume, "125 Years' Swiss History of Time," further commemorated the history of the company.{{cite news |date= |title=Interview with Mr. Sascha Moeri, CEO of Carl F. Bucherer |url=http://digital.modernluxury.com/publication/?i=198773&article_id=1645968&view=articleBrowser&ver=html5 |newspaper=Watches International 2014 |publisher=Tourbillon International }} ==Partnership with Swiss Football Association== In 2014, Carl F. Bucherer partnered with the Swiss National Football Association, providing each member of the [[Switzerland national football team|Swiss national football team]] a Patravi ScubaTec SFV Special Edition watch ahead of that year's [[2014 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].{{cite news |date=27 March 2014 |title=«König Fussball» regiert an der Basler Uhrenmesse |url=http://www.nzz.ch/wirtschaft/newsticker/baselworldkoenig-fussball-regiert-an-der-basler-uhrenmesse-1.18272080 |newspaper=Neue Zürcher Zeitung }}{{cite web |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/news/detail/carl-f-bucherer-teams-up-with-the-swiss-football-association/ |title=Carl F. Bucherer Teams Up with the Swiss Football Association |date=24 March 2014 |publisher=Carl F. Bucherer }} The logo of the Swiss Football Association is at 6 o'clock on the bezel. The back case of each watch has an engraving of the individual player's name.{{cite news |date=1 July 2014 |title=Argentina vs. Switzerland FIFA World Cup Matchup: Leo Messi's Audemars Piguet Takes On Diego Benaglio's Carl F. Bucherer And More |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/elizabethdoerr/2014/07/01/argentina-vs-switzerland-fifa-world-cup-matchup-leo-messis-audemars-piguet-takes-on-diego-benaglios-carl-f-bucherer-and-more/ |newspaper=Forbes }} As of 1 July 2016, Carl F. Bucherer is the "Official Timekeeper" for the Swiss national football teams for a period of four years.{{cite news |date=25 May 2016 |title=Official Timekeeper of The Swiss National Football Teams |url=http://www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/news/official-timekeeper-of-swiss-national-football-teams |agency=Carl F. Bucherer }} As part of this partnership, Swiss national players are wearing the exclusive Patravi ScubaTec SFV timepiece. The press conference announcing the partnership was attended by [[Stephan Lichtsteiner]], captain of the Swiss national team, and star player [[Granit Xhaka]].{{cite news |date=26 May 2016 |title=Carl F. Bucherer: Official Timekeeper of the Swiss National Football Team |url=http://en.worldtempus.com/article/industry-news/carl-f-bucherer-official-timekeeper-swiss-national-football-team-2454703 |agency=WorldTempus }}{{cite news |date=26 May 2016 |title=Bucherer misst die Zeit von Xhaka und Co. |url=http://www.jungfrauzeitung.ch/artikel/144556/ |newspaper=Jungfrau Zeitung }} == Cultural References == In the 2018 movie [[Deadpool 2]] the character [[Cable (comics)|Cable]], a time-travelling soldier played by [[Josh Brolin]], uses a time-machine on his wrist to move through time. In close-ups of the device it is inscribed with the Carl F. Bucherer name and logo suggesting that, far in the future where Cable originates, the watchmaker produces wearable time pieces that can manipulate time itself. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official|www.carl-f-bucherer.com/en/home/}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1888 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1888]] [[Category:Luxury brands]] [[Category:Swiss watch brands]] [[Category:Watch brands]] [[Category:Watch manufacturing companies of Switzerland]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1888]]

'''Chehel Minbari''' is a special tradition practiced in [[Iran|Iran's]] western [[Lorestān Province]], in which thousands of women commemorate the martyrdom anniversary of [[Husayn ibn Ali|Imam Hussein]].
Women from cities and towns across Lorestān Province cover their faces completely with black cloth and walk in silence as they knock on the doors of 40 houses and light candles in 40 spots as mourners beat their chests in their grief over the suffering and martyrdom of Imam Hussein along with 72 of his loyal companions in [[Karbala]] in [[southern Iraq]], in 680 CE.
The Chehel Minbari tradition is upheld every year on Tasu'a (which is on the 9th of [[Muharram]]), as a show of solidarity with the sister of Imam Hussein, [[Zaynab bint Ali|Hazrat Zainab]]. Shia mourners throughout the world gather on Tasu'a to commemorate the martyrdom anniversary of Imam Hussein.
The Chehel Minbari ritual starts after participants have said their dawn prayers and ends at dusk prayers.
==See also== *[[Mourning of Muharram]] *[[Day of Ashura]]

page.title: Confession inscriptions of Lydia and Phrygia

revision.text:
'''Confession inscriptions of [[Lydia]] and [[Phrygia]]''' are Roman-era [[Koine Greek]] religious [[stele]]s from these historical regions of [[Anatolia]] (then part of [[Asia (Roman province)|Asia]] and [[Galatia (Roman province)|Galatia]] provinces), dating mostly to the 2nd and 3rd centuries. The new element that appears, the public [[Confession (religion)|confession]] of sin and the [[redemption (theology)|redemption]] through offerings (lytra), unknown to traditional [[Religion in ancient Greece|Greek religion]], has made scholars to name this social phenomenon as oriental. The religious thought and the use of vernacular Koine Greek, full of innovative orthography,syntax and grammar, suggests that they may also represent something at the root of religion in Phrygia and Lydia.Angels and Principalities: The Background, Meaning and Development of the Pauline Phrase hai archai kai hai exousiai A. Wesley Carr [https://books.google.com/books?id=Cnjptnn7EjEC&pg=PA56&dq=Phrygia+Lydia++inscriptions+oriental+confession#v=onepage&q=&f=false Page 56] {{ISBN|0-521-23429-8}} (2005) Marijana Ricl has argued that the practice of confession is a reminiscence of [[Hittite religion]]. According to Schnabel E.J it was a counter-move prompted by the increasing success of the Christian missionaries.Deutungen des Todes Jesu im neuen Testament edited by Jörg Frey, Jens Schröter [https://books.google.com/books?id=upHACoCciKQC&pg=PA292&dq=a+counter-move+prompted+by+the+increasing+success+of+the+Christian+missionaries#v=onepage&q=a%20counter-move%20prompted%20by%20the%20increasin Page 292] {{ISBN|3-16-148581-5}} (2007) Indeed, beside the scheme of confession/redemption, phraseology and terms remind of Greek [[New Testament]]: [[hamartia]] (sin), [[paraclete|parakletos]] (advocator), [[Slavery in antiquity|doulos]] tou theou (slave of god), [[kyrios]] (master), [[basileus]] (king). Another point for discussion is the punishment of sexual transgressions, which further relates the inscriptions to Christianity and the concept of [[chastity]] in [[:Category:Hellenistic philosophy and religion|Hellenistic philosophy and religion]]; in contrast to the previous perception of sexuality inside the religion ([[Hieros gamos]], [[Sacred prostitution]], [[Aphrodite Pandemos]]). Some indicating names or epithets of deities engaged in the inscriptions are: [[Men (god)|Men]] (Axiottenos, Artemidoros), Meter (mother), [[Zeus]] (Aithrios, Keraunios, Soter), [[Apollo]], [[Hypsistos]], [[Anaitis]], [[Attis]], [[Dionysos]], Hades, [[Herakles]], [[Sabazios]], Batenos, [[Nemesis (mythology)|Nemesis]], [[Asclepius]], Tyrannos, Basileus, Theos Strapton and Bronton, [[Hecate]], [[Artemis]] etc. ==Inscriptions== ===Ritual dialogue of Theodoros with the Gods (Lydia, 235/236 AD) === {| ! Koine Greek original text[http://epigraphy.packhum.org/inscriptions/oi?ikey=277422&bookid=172®ion=8&subregion=30 SEG 38:1237] [[Manisa]] Museum, fr. NE Lydia !
