'''''Mirror's Edge''''' is a first-person [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[Platform game|platform]] video game developed by [[EA DICE]] and published by [[Electronic Arts]]. The game was announced in July 2007, and was released for the [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation 3]] in November 2008. A [[Microsoft Windows]] version was released on January 13, 2009. ''Mirror's Edge'' is powered by [[Unreal Engine 3]], with the addition of a new lighting solution, developed by [[Illuminate Labs]] in association with DICE.
''Mirror's Edge'' is set in a quasi-futuristic [[dystopia]]n society, in which a network of 'runners', including the main character, [[Faith Connors]], act as couriers to transmit messages while evading government surveillance. In the style of a three-dimensional [[platform game]], the player guides Faith over rooftops, across walls, through ventilation shafts, and otherwise within urban environments, negotiating obstacles using movements inspired by [[parkour]]. The game has a brightly colored, [[Minimalism|minimalist]] style and differs from most previous first-person perspective video games in allowing for a greater freedom of movement with regard to its 3D environment. This allows for a wider range of actions—such as sliding under barriers, tumbling, wall-running, and shimmying across ledges; in having no [[HUD (video gaming)|heads-up display]]; and in allowing a range of vision which incorporated the legs, arms, and torso of the character as frequently visible elements on-screen.
''Mirror's Edge'' has received positive reviews, with the PC version garnering a [[Metacritic]] aggregated score of 81. The game's uniqueness and its expansive environments have received praise, while criticism has centred on its weakness of plot, trial and error gameplay, and short length. The game won the [[Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences#Annual Interactive Achievement Awards|Annual Interactive Achievement Award]] for Adventure Game of the Year. A [[Still Alive: The Remixes|soundtrack]] featuring remixes of the final credits song "Still Alive" by Swedish singer [[Lisa Miskovsky]] was also released. A [[Side-scrolling video game|side-scroller]] mobile game, also titled ''Mirror's Edge'', was released for [[iPad]] on April 1, 2010, and for the [[iPhone]] on September 2, 2010. The mobile game was ported to [[Windows Phone]] on July 13, 2012, with an initial exclusivity period for owners of [[Microsoft Lumia|Nokia Lumia]] phones. A prequel, ''[[Mirror's Edge Catalyst]]'', was officially announced at the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2013]] and released on June 7, 2016.
==Gameplay== [[File:Mirrors-Edge-scr1.jpg|thumb|left|256px|alt=A uniformed soldier, standing on a rooftop, falls back after being kicked. Two arms and a leg belonging to the player's character are visible.|''Mirror's Edge'' features a realistic [[First person (video games)|first-person view]], with the character's limbs visible during [[hand-to-hand combat]].]]
In ''Mirror's Edge'', the player controls the protagonist, Faith, from a first-person perspective as she is challenged to navigate across a gleaming city by jumping between rooftops, running across walls, and gaining access to buildings through ventilation shafts. This is accomplished by use of techniques and movements inspired by the discipline of [[parkour]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8zZKRVkZvtA |title=Mirror's Edge interview by Gamereactor |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=July 15, 2012}}</ref> According to [[Video game producer|senior producer]] Owen O'Brien, ''Mirror's Edge'' aims to "convey [...] strain and physical contact with the environment", with the goal of allowing a freedom of movement previously unseen in the first-person genre.<ref name="1Upprev1">{{cite web|last=Suttner |first=Nick |publisher=1UP.com |title=''Mirror's Edge'' Preview |url=http://www.1up.com/do/previewPage?cId=3166742 |date=February 29, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="Edgemag">{{cite web|author=Edge staff |title=Leap of Faith: DICE's ''Mirror's Edge'' |work=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |date=July 29, 2007 |url=http://www.next-gen.biz/features/leap-faith-dices-mirrors-edge |accessdate=February 4, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In order to achieve this, camera movement pays more attention to character movement. For example, as Faith's speed builds up while running, the rate at which the camera bobs up and down increases as well. When a roll is executed, the camera spins with the character.<ref name="ignprev">{{cite web |last=Ahearn |first=Nate |publisher=IGN |title= ''Mirror's Edge'' First Look – Xbox 360 Preview |url=http://xbox360.ign.com/articles/855/855848p1.html |date=February 29, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Wilson |first=Mark |publisher=Kotaku |title=Experiencing Hyperreality, ''Mirror's Edge'' Impressions |url=http://kotaku.com/362114/experiencing-hyperreality-mirrors-edge-impressions |date=February 29, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref> Faith's arms, legs, and torso are prominent and their visibility is used to convey movement and momentum. The character's arms pump and the length of her steps increase with her gait, and her legs cycle and arms flail during long jumps.<ref name="ignprev"/><ref name="Edge">{{cite web |last=Plunkett |first=Luke |publisher=Kotaku |title=''Mirror's Edge'' Sounds Pretty Great |url=http://kotaku.com/gaming/kotaku-magu/mirrors-edge-sounds-pretty-great-281164.php |date=July 23, 2007 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070728155653/http://kotaku.com/gaming/kotaku-magu/mirrors-edge-sounds-pretty-great-281164.php |archivedate=July 28, 2007 }}</ref>
In gameplay, the character's [[momentum]] becomes an asset. The player must attempt to conserve it through fluidity of physical actions, encouraging the creation of chains of moves.<ref name="runnervision">{{cite web |last=Pellett |first=Matthew |publisher=[[Computer and Video Games|CVG]] |title=Preview: ''Mirror's Edge''|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=188249 |date=May 4, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref> If Faith does not have the momentum required to traverse an object, she will fall off or short of it.<ref name="euro">{{cite web |last=Bramwell |first=Tom |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |title=''Mirror's Edge'' Preview |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=93740 |date=February 29, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref> Controls are simplified by being context-sensitive; the "upwards movement" button will cause Faith to traverse an obstacle by passing over it (i.e., by jumping, vaulting, climbing, or grabbing set pieces like [[zip-line]]s) while the "downwards movement" button will cause her to perform other manoeuvres like sliding, rolling, or crouching.<ref name="euro"/><ref name="ars">{{cite web |last=Kuchera |first= Ben |publisher=Ars Technica|title= GDC: First peek at ''Mirror's Edge''; don't look down! |url=https://arstechnica.com/journals/thumbs.ars/2008/02/29/notes-for-embargoed-mirrors-edge |date=February 29, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref> To assist the player in creating these chains of moves, the game employs a system called "Runner Vision", which emphasizes environmental pieces useful for progression. Certain pipes, ramps, and doors are highlighted in [[red]] as Faith approaches, allowing the player to instantly recognize paths and escape routes.<ref name="euro"/> Further along in the game, the number of these visual hints is reduced to only the end goal, and the player can opt to turn off this hint system entirely.<ref name="runnervision"/> It is also used to create puzzles in which the player must figure out how to combine the highlighted set pieces into a chain of moves in order to reach the target.<ref name="euro"/> Another means of assistance to the player is a system called "Reaction Time", a form of [[bullet time]] activated by the player, slowing down time and allowing the player to plan and time their next move without losing momentum or tactical advantage.<ref name="ars"/>
The player character can hold weapons, but O'Brien stressed that "this is an action adventure. We're not positioning this as a shooter – the focus isn't on the gun, it's on the person." Gameplay in ''Mirror's Edge'' focuses on finding the best route through the game's environments while combat takes a secondary role. Completing the game without shooting a single enemy unlocks an achievement for the player.<ref name="1Upprev1"/> Consequently, guns may be obtained by disarming an enemy, but when the magazine is empty, it will need to be discarded.<ref name="runnervision"/> Additionally, carrying a weapon slows Faith down; the heavier the gun, the more it hinders her movement. This introduces an element of strategy in determining when to trade agility for short-term firepower.<ref name="1Upprev1"/><ref name="euro"/>
Along with the campaign mode, ''Mirror's Edge'' features a [[time attack#Videogame|time attack]] mode, where the player must try to complete one of a set of special maps in the shortest amount of time. Best times can be uploaded to online leaderboards, where players can also download [[Glossary of video game terms#G|ghosts]] of other players to compete against.<ref name=dicemappackrelease>{{cite web|url=http://www.ea.com/news/downloadable-time-trial-map-pack-for-mirrors-edge|title=DICE Releases All-New Downloadable Time Trial Map Pack for ''Mirror's Edge''|date=February 19, 2009|publisher=EA|accessdate=October 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=joystiqtt>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2008/10/07/joystiq-hands-on-mirrors-edge-time-trial-mode/|last=Nelson|title=Joystiq hands-on: ''Mirror's Edge'' time trial mode|first=Randy|date=November 7, 2008|accessdate=October 26, 2009|publisher=Joystiq}}</ref> The maps are unlocked by playing through the campaign mode. According to producer Tom Ferrer, the time trial portions of ''Mirror's Edge'' are "bite-sized and short so you can grind them and play them and get faster and faster. It's not like playing an entire level."<ref name="1up-trial">{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3169616|publisher=1UP.com|title=''Mirror's Edge'' Features Time-Trial Mode|last=Kollar|first=Phillip|date=August 27, 2008|accessdate=October 26, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DE98Q1W?url=http://www.1up.com/news/mirror-edge-features-time-trial-mode|archivedate=June 6, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The mobile phone port includes many parkour moves from the PC and console versions, however, the perspective is shifted from first person to third person. The game does not feature cutscenes, and the plot is explained with scrolling text in between levels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/mirrors-edge-2d-edition/iphone-54021|title=Mirror's Edge [2D Edition] (iPhone)|website=IGN|access-date=March 9, 2016}}</ref> The iOS version has since been removed from the app store due to problems with the game on iOS 8.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://help.ea.com/en/article/some-ea-games-are-being-removed-from-the-app-store/|title=Some EA games are being removed from the App Store|website=help.ea.com|access-date=March 9, 2016}}</ref>
==Plot==
===Setting=== ''Mirror's Edge'' takes place in a 'utopian' city<ref name="sickness">{{cite web |last=Totilo |first=Stephen |publisher= MTV | title= EA Discusses ''Mirror's Edge'' Sickness Concerns, Lack Of Color Green |url= http://www.mtv.com/news/2456471/ea-discusses-mirrors-edge-sickness-concerns-lack-of-color-green/ | date= March 7, 2008 | accessdate=May 12, 2008}}</ref> where life is comfortable and crime almost non-existent. But the city's state of bliss is the achievement of a domineering and [[totalitarianism|totalitarian]] [[Military dictatorship|military regime]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.playstation.com/games-media/games/detail/item101965/Mirrors-Edge%E2%84%A2/|accessdate=February 16, 2010|publisher=uk.playstation.com|title=Playstation Games – ''Mirror's Edge''}}</ref> which [[Mass surveillance|monitors all communication]], controls the media, spies on its citizens and has policies which include the outright prohibition of [[smoking]] and [[alcohol]]. The City also operates [[show trial]]s and runs on a [[Totalitarian democracy|sham democracy]]. Eighteen years before the events of the game, they had opened fire on a protest against their rule, killing many civilians.
As the story begins the mayoral elections are near and a new candidate, Robert Pope, is challenging the incumbent Mayor Callaghan on a platform of [[deregulation]].
===Themes=== According to senior producer Owen O'Brien, "[Mirror's Edge] asks how much of your [[personal freedom]] are you willing to give up for a comfortable life. It's not one girl against this [[Police state|police-state]] dictatorship. It's more subtle than that."<ref name="gamasutra08">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3684/living_on_the_edge_dices_owen_.php|title=Living On The Edge: DICE's Owen O'Brien Speaks|author=Christian Nutt|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=June 6, 2008}}</ref>
American TV series ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'' and film spin-off ''[[Serenity (2005 film)|Serenity]]'' were cited by O'Brien as inspirations. "Our other theme is you can't force other people to live by your rules and your society, even if your society is better," he said. "In Serenity The Operative actually says, 'This is not an evil empire. We just don't understand why you don't want to be part of our happy club.' Obviously they take it too far, and that's kind of what happens in our game as well."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3684/living_on_the_edge_dices_owen_.php?page=4|title=Living On The Edge: DICE's Owen O'Brien Speaks|author=Christian Nutt|page=4|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=June 6, 2008}}</ref>
Writer Rhianna Pratchett has said that the game's story examined why citizens would accept a life in a society where their personal choices were very limited. It also looked at reasons people might have for attempting to live outside the system and what could result from this. The society portrayed in the game was somewhere between what [[George Orwell]] described as an 'anti-utopia' and a Nanny State.<ref name="Mirror's_Edge_newsarama">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/1896-looking-at-the-mirror-s-edge-with-rhianna-pratchett.html|title=Looking at the Mirror's Edge with Rhianna Pratchett|last=Robison|first=Seth|publisher=[[Newsarama]]|date=January 7, 2009|accessdate=November 9, 2014}}</ref>
===Characters=== {{See also|Faith Connors}} The protagonist of ''Mirror's Edge'' is 24-year-old Faith Connors (voiced by [[Jules de Jongh]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asiaarts.ucla.edu/090102/article.asp?parentid=102616 |publisher=UCLA Asia Institute |date=January 2, 2009 |accessdate=February 2, 2010 |title=Best of 2008: Asian-themed Video Games |last=Hong |first=William |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719055057/http://asiaarts.ucla.edu/090102/article.asp?parentid=102616 |archivedate=July 19, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/12/review-mirrors-edge-xbox-360.html|work=''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]''|date=December 8, 2009|title=''Mirror's Edge'' (Xbox 360)|last=Killingsworth|first=Jason|accessdate=February 4, 2010}}</ref> who has a distinctive tattoo around her right eye, imitated by the game's logo. Faith earns her living as a "Runner", a [[courier]] who carries physical communiqués around the city, her services retained by revolutionary groups who avoid communicating via highly monitored [[telephone]] and [[email]] channels.<ref name="1Upprev1"/> Faith's attitude towards the totalitarian government is rooted in her past; her parents were active in protest movements when she was young, campaigning to keep the city from shifting to the oppressive regime. Her mother was killed during the "November riots"—peaceful protests gone wrong<ref name="Mirror's Edge">{{cite video game|title=Mirror's Edge|developer=[[EA Digital Illusions CE]]|publisher=[[Electronic Arts]]|date=November 12, 2008|platform=[[PlayStation 3]]/[[Xbox 360]]/[[Microsoft Windows]]|version=|scene=|level=|quote=}}</ref>—and Faith ran away from home when she was 16, living a thief's life on the city streets. Faith became a Runner after meeting Mercury (or Merc), a former Runner who now trains new hires, sources jobs for them, and provides them with intelligence and radio support while on the job.<ref name=GameTrailers>{{cite web| url = http://www.gametrailers.com/videos/iw455d/mirror-s-edge-run-story-trailer| title = ''Mirror's Edge'' Video Game, Run Story Trailer HD | author = [[GameTrailers]]|date=August 16, 2008| accessdate = April 3, 2014| postscript =}}</ref> Other characters include Faith's sister, Kate Connors, an officer with the city [[police]]; Drake, another Runner-trainer; Faith's friends Celeste and Kreeg, another pair of Merc's Runners; and Jacknife, a former Runner.<ref name="Mirror's Edge"/>
===Story=== Faith, after completing a delivery to fellow Runner Celeste, learns that her sister Kate may be in trouble at Pope's office. When she arrives, she finds Kate standing beside Pope's body, insisting she has been framed for murder and requesting Faith to discover the cause. Faith finds a piece of paper with the name "Icarus" on it in Pope's hand. Kate refuses to flee with Faith, saying it would only make her look guilty, and is arrested.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Mirror's Edge|developer=[[EA Digital Illusions CE]]|publisher=[[Electronic Arts]]|date=November 12, 2008|platform=[[PlayStation 3]]/[[Xbox 360]]/[[Microsoft Windows]]|version=|scene=|level=Chapter 1: Flight|quote='''Faith''': Kate? / '''Kate''': ''[turns to face her]'' What are you doing here? / '''Faith''': ''[regarding the body]'' What happened? Did you—? / '''Kate''': No! You don't recognize him? / '''Faith''': Should I? / '''Kate''': It's Robert. Robert Pope, friend of Dad's. / '''Faith''': ''Shit.'' That Pope… ''[…]'' You think this was an accident, Kate? There ''are'' no accidents in this city. Someone wanted ''him'' dead, and wanted ''you'' to take the fall. ''[…]'' / '''Kate''': If this goes down badly, find Lieutenant Miller. My superior. Take anything you find to him.}}</ref> From a former Runner, Jacknife, Faith learns that Pope's head of security, former wrestler Travis "Ropeburn" Burfield, may be connected to Pope's murder. Faith meets Lt. Miller, at Kate's behest, narrowly avoiding arrest.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Mirror's Edge|developer=[[EA Digital Illusions CE]]|publisher=[[Electronic Arts]]|date=November 12, 2008|platform=[[PlayStation 3]]/[[Xbox 360]]/[[Microsoft Windows]]|version=|scene=Cinematic|level=|quote='''Faith''': Kate's the only family I have. And Blues in jail don't last long. She goes down for this, it's a death sentence.}}</ref> At Ropeburn's office, she overhears him setting up a meeting at a new place downtown. At the meeting, Ropeburn discovers Faith's presence and attacks her, but Faith gains the upper hand and throws him off the roof. As he is hanging above a long drop, she tries to interrogate Ropeburn, but before he can reveal anything he is killed by an unknown assassin.
Lacking other leads, Faith investigates the security firm that has begun aiding the police force in their crackdown of Runners. She finds they are behind "Project Icarus", a program designed to train their forces in [[parkour]] style to oppose the Runners, giving them the ability to chase down and eliminate the Runners. Faith follows the trail of Ropeburn's killer to a boat in port; after chasing the unknown person, Faith discovers the assassin is actually Celeste, who is colluding with Project Icarus to keep herself safe, and Celeste warns Faith to consider the same. The arrival of the police allows Celeste to escape.<ref name="Mirror's Edge"/>
With Kate convicted for Pope's murder, Merc plans a way for Faith to ambush the police convoy transporting her to prison, and Faith helps to free Kate. She gives Kate her comms unit that she and Merc use and tells her that he will guide her back to his hideout. When Faith returns to the hideout, she finds it in ruins, with Merc dying and Kate recaptured. In his dying words, Merc tells Faith that Kate is now at the Shard, which contains Mayor Callaghan's office and the servers that run the city's surveillance systems.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Mirror's Edge|developer=[[EA Digital Illusions CE]]|publisher=[[Electronic Arts]]|date=November 12, 2008|platform=[[PlayStation 3]]/[[Xbox 360]]/[[Microsoft Windows]]|version=|scene=Cinematic|level=|quote='''Merc''': Heard them mention…the Shard. / '''Faith''': The mayor's place?}}</ref> With Miller's help, Faith is able to enter the Mayor's private offices, and destroys the servers that will unlock the rooftop security door. She gains access to the roof, but Miller was also ambushed while in the security room, abruptly cutting off communications, leaving Miller's status unknown. On the roof, she finds Kate held at gunpoint by Jacknife. Jacknife reveals that he too is part of Project Icarus, and has been part of the plan all along to lure the Runners out of hiding. When Jacknife tries to take Kate onto a waiting helicopter, Faith jumps on before it can leave, knocking Jacknife out of the helicopter to fall to his death but also damaging the helicopter in the process. Faith helps Kate to escape safely from the falling helicopter.<ref name="Mirror's Edge"/>
During the [[Closing credits|end credits]], the media reports that Faith's actions have only served to intensify Project Icarus, and Faith and Kate are still wanted for Pope's murder. However, with the surveillance infrastructure damaged, the population is cautioned to avoid using electronic means of communications until their "security" is restored, with the location of Faith and Kate remaining unknown.
==Development and release== In 2007, DICE creative director Ben Cousins told GamesIndustry.biz that the studio was looking to create "something fresh and interesting", anticipating a need to diversify away from the successful ''[[Battlefield (video game series)|Battlefield]]'' franchise the studio was known for.<ref>{{cite web |last=Martin |first=Matt |title=DICE promises to diversify with new projects |publisher=GamesIndustry.biz |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/dice-promises-to-diversify-with-new-projects |date=June 11, 2007 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref>
In June 2007, ''[[Computer and Video Games]]'' magazine revealed that DICE was working on a game called ''Mirror's Edge'', which was expected to "shake up the [first-person shooter] genre".<ref>{{cite web |last=Ogden |first=Gavin |publisher=Computer and Video Games |title=New DICE shooter revealed |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=166931 |date=June 29, 2007 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref> On July 10, 2007, ''Mirror's Edge'' was officially announced by [[Electronic Arts]], and at the [[Game Developers Conference]] in San Francisco in February 2008, the first demonstration of gameplay was shown.<ref name="ars"/> A video featuring entirely in-game footage was released at the Sony PlayStation Day in London on May 6, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |last=Fahey |first=Mike |publisher=Kotaku |title=''Mirror's Edge'' In Motion |url=http://kotaku.com/387711/mirrors-edge-in-motion |date=May 6, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref>
{{quote box|width=35%|quote=The art direction grew out of the gameplay. We wanted to give people a sense of the world very quickly and move through it very quickly. We initially stripped out all of the colors and then just put in red [to guide people to objectives]... I wanted a game where I could look at a screenshot and say, "Hey, that's ''Mirror's Edge.''"|source=Owen O'Brien<ref name=sickness/>}}
''Mirror's Edge'' has a distinct visual style, with the outdoor environments predominantly featuring [[white]] and distinctively lacking in [[green]] (for example, trees and foliage would appear completely white instead of in their natural colours), punctuated by deliberate use of strong [[primary color|primary colours]]. According to Senior Producer Owen O'Brien, the stylistic choice allows the player to focus on the Runner Vision guidance, as well as serving as a [[health (gaming)|health meter]]; the colours become less saturated as Faith starts to take damage.<ref name=sickness/> Because development of ''Mirror's Edge'' began before DICE's own [[Frostbite (game engine)|Frostbite]] was completed, the game uses [[Epic Games|Epic]]'s Unreal Engine 3. A [[Global illumination|lighting system]] called "[[Beast (lighting software)|Beast]]" was developed for the Unreal Engine by [[Illuminate Labs]] in association with DICE. The new software would accentuate the different art style of ''Mirror's Edge'', by allowing for the reflection of colours as well as light.<ref name="unreal">{{cite web |last=Miller |first=Ross |title=''Mirror's Edge'' reflects on Unreal Engine 3 |publisher=Joystiq |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2008/05/07/mirrors-edge-reflects-on-unreal-engine-3 |date=May 7, 2008 |accessdate=May 8, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher=[[Illuminate Labs]] |title= ''Mirror's Edge'' | url=http://www.illuminatelabs.com/gallery/mirror-s-edge |accessdate= May 12, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916084446/http://www.illuminatelabs.com/gallery/mirror-s-edge |archivedate=September 16, 2010 }}</ref> In order to address the issue of [[Motion sickness#Simulation sickness|simulation sickness]] associated with the free movement of the camera in first-person view, a small [[reticle]] was placed in the centre of the screen. The reticle serves as an aiming and focal point, preventing dizziness in similar fashion to the dance technique called [[spotting (dance technique)|spotting]]. Aside from this reticle (which can be hidden by the player), no [[HUD (video gaming)|heads-up display]] exists in the game.<ref name="sickness"/><ref>{{cite web |last= Yin-Poole |first=Wesley | publisher=[[Videogamer.com]] | title= ''Mirror's Edge'' Interview | url= http://www.videogamer.com/xbox360/mirrors_edge/preview-912-2.html | date= May 9, 2008 | accessdate= May 13, 2008}}</ref>
The [[Game demo|demo]] for ''Mirror's Edge'', consisting of the game's [[prologue]] chapter, was released via the [[PlayStation Store]] on October 30, 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shacknews.com/onearticle.x/55659|title=PlayStation Store Update: ''Mirror's Edge'' Demo, ''EndWar'' Demo and ''Siren: Blood Curse'' Sale|last=Faylor|first=Chris|accessdate=October 26, 2009|date=October 30, 2008|publisher=[[Shacknews]]}}</ref> followed by the [[Xbox Games Store|Xbox LIVE Marketplace]] on October 31. On November 7, 2008, DICE announced that ''Mirror's Edge'' had achieved [[Software release life cycle|gold status]], and PS3 and Xbox 360 versions would be shipping to retailers on November 13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planetxbox360.com/article_5042/DICE_Announces_that_Mirrors_Edge_has_Gone_Gold|title=DICE Announces that ''Mirror's Edge'' has Gone Gold|last=Bush|first=Eric|date= November 7, 2008|publisher=Planet Xbox 360|accessdate=February 2, 2010}}</ref> On January 16, 2009, a [[Games for Windows|Microsoft Windows]] version of the game was released.<ref name="mepcrd-shachn">{{cite web|url=http://www.shacknews.com/onearticle.x/56209|title=''Mirror's Edge'' PC Release January 16; Time Trial DLC Late January|last=Goldstein|first=Maarten |date=December 4, 2008|publisher=[[Shacknews]]|accessdate=December 5, 2008}}</ref> The PC version features support for [[Nvidia]]'s [[PhysX]], adding detail and physics to glass, smoke and soft materials. The game includes the [[SecuROM]] v7.x (activation based) [[Digital rights management|DRM]] software,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://knowyourgame.reclaimyourgame.com/tiki-index.php?page=List+of+games+with+SecuROM+7 |title=Games with SecuROM 7 |publisher=Know Your Game! Tiki |accessdate=February 3, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130083423/http://knowyourgame.reclaimyourgame.com/tiki-index.php?page=list%2Bof%2Bgames%2Bwith%2BSecuROM%2B7 |archivedate=January 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> unless bought from [[Steam (software)|Steam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/bigname_electronic_arts_games_now_steam_securom_not|publisher=|work=Maximum PC|date=December 22, 2008|last=Grayson|first=Nathan|title=Big-Name Electronic Arts Games Now on Steam, SecuROM Not|accessdate=February 3, 2010}}</ref>
The game was at the centre of EA's [[Edge Games#Electronic Arts petition for trademark cancellation|conflict with Edge Games]], a California-based development studio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/aspx/stock-market-news-story.aspx?storyid=200909291639dowjonesdjonline000434&title=ea-gets-aggressive-in-edgetrademark-spat-with-game-maker|title=EA Gets Aggressive In 'Edge' Trademark Spat With Game Maker|date=September 29, 2009|last=Charny|first=Ben|publisher=[[NASDAQ]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/ea-takes-up-edge-trademark-fight|title=EA takes up Edge trademark fight|last=Bramwell|first=Tom|date=September 30, 2009|accessdate=September 30, 2009|publisher=GamesIndustry.biz}}</ref> [[Edge Games]] is not related to [[Edge (magazine)|''Edge'' magazine]] beyond the licensing of its trademark. In September 2009, EA petitioned to have Edge Games' trademarks cancelled, alleging continued threats of legal action. [[Tim Langdell]], president of Edge Games, responded by accusing EA of engaging Edge Games in settlement talks as a "play for time". Langdell's company claimed true legal ownership of the phrase "Mirror's Edge" among other variations of "Edge".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/95116-Tim-Langdell-Responds-to-EA-Trademark-Petition|last=Chalk|first=Andy|title=Tim Langdell Responds to EA Trademark Petition|publisher=[[The Escapist (website)|The Escapist]]|date=September 30, 2009}}</ref> After a court found that Edge Games' claims were "suspect", the company settled with EA and surrendered many of its trademarks.<ref name="settlement">{{citation|url=http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/ttabvue-92051465-CAN-32.pdf|title=Trademark settlement|mode=cs1|accessdate=November 22, 2013}}</ref>
===Marketing campaign=== Buyers who pre-ordered ''Mirror's Edge'' at [[GameCrazy]] received a code that unlocked a time trial portion of the demo, as well as a ''Mirror's Edge''-themed [[t-shirt]]. A time trial code was also included in [[GameStop]] preorders, along with a yellow "Runner Bag" resembling the [[messenger bag]]s used in the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalsomething.com/news/1149.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106054717/http://www.digitalsomething.com/news/1149.html|archivedate=January 6, 2011|title=''Mirror's Edge'' Pre-Order Swag Bag ... Literally!|first=Scott|last=Ferguson|date= July 30, 2008|accessdate=October 26, 2009}}</ref> Preorders from UK retailer [[Game (retailer)|Game]] included a ''Mirror's Edge''-edition [[Fenchurch (clothing)|Fenchurch]] t-shirt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/mirror-s-edge-has-gone-gold|title=''Mirror's Edge''|date=June 11, 2008|accessdate=October 26, 2009|work=GamesIndustry.biz}}</ref> The game could also be bought through the Electronic Arts website, where a package deal with a red [[Timbuk2]] messenger bag was available. The bag featured the game's logo on the outside, while the inside featured a portrait of Faith.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5055096/mirrors-edge-expensive-collectors-edition|title=''Mirror's Edge'' Expensive Collectors Edition|date= September 25, 2008 |accessdate=October 26, 2009|last=Plunkett|first=Luke}}</ref>
===Comics=== During [[San Diego Comic-Con|Comic-Con]] 2008, DICE announced it would create a limited-run [[comic book]] adaptation of the game together with [[DC Comics]] division [[WildStorm]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Guilfoil |first=John M. |url=http://blastmagazine.com/the-magazine/technology/2008/07/comic-con-2008-ea-and-dc-create-mirrors-edge-comic-book/ |title=Comic-con 2008: E.A. and D.C. create ''Mirror's Edge'' comic book|work=Blast |date=July 26, 2009 |accessdate=February 2, 2010 }}</ref> The six-issue comic is drawn by [[Matthew Dow Smith]] and written by [[Rhianna Pratchett]].<ref name="destructoid_comicon08_comic">{{cite web |last=Chester |first=Nick |url=http://www.destructoid.com/comic-con-08-ea-and-dc-team-up-for-mirror-s-edge-comic-book-96745.phtml |title=Comic-Con 08: EA and DC team up for ''Mirror's Edge'' comic book |publisher=[[Destructoid]] |date=July 24, 2008 |accessdate=December 11, 2008 }}</ref>
===Soundtrack=== {{Main|Still Alive: The Remixes}}
In May, the ''Mirror's Edge Original Videogame Score'' was released in online-only form. The album was composed by Swedish electronic musician [[Solar Fields|Magnus Birgersson]], also known as Solar Fields,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0026WJFOC|title=''Mirror's Edge'' Original Videogame Score}}</ref> who stated that "the music should reflect the environment, the story, the gameplay and Faith's mood" and that the soundtrack is a mixture of electronic and ambient music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plurall.com/forum/comunidade/international-area/21774-interview-mirror-s-edge-music-composer-magnus-birgersson-aka-solar-fields/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120908111633/http://www.plurall.com/forum/comunidade/international-area/21774-interview-mirror-s-edge-music-composer-magnus-birgersson-aka-solar-fields/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 8, 2012 |title=Interview with ''Mirror's Edge'' Music Composer Magnus Birgersson (aka Solar Fields) |accessdate=February 2, 2010 |publisher=Music4Games }}</ref>
On October 7, 2008, EA announced the release of a remix album featuring the ''Mirror's Edge'' theme song "Still Alive" by musician [[Lisa Miskovsky]]. Contributing artists included [[Benny Benassi]], [[Junkie XL]], [[Paul van Dyk]], [[Teddybears (band)|Teddybears]] and [[Armand Van Helden]]. Although "Still Alive" is also the name of the closing credits song of 2007 game ''[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]'', the two tracks are unrelated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neoseeker.com/news/8981-mirrors-edge-soundtrack-will-feature-still-alive-/|title=''Mirror's Edge'' soundtrack will feature "Still Alive"|work=Neoseeker|last=Sung|first=Lydia|date=October 7, 2008|accessdate=February 3, 2010}}</ref> The album, titled ''Still Alive – the Remixes'', was released on November 11, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ea.com/portal/site/ea/index.jsp?ndmViewId=news_view&ndmConfigId=1012492&newsId=20081007005420&newsLang=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210064319/http://news.ea.com/portal/site/ea/index.jsp?ndmViewId=news_view&ndmConfigId=1012492&newsId=20081007005420&newsLang=en |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 10, 2008 |title=DICE Announces ''Mirror's Edge'' Remix Album Hitting Airwaves This November |publisher=EA |date=October 7, 2008 |accessdate=October 7, 2008 |df= }}</ref> The album was included free in the standard game in later releases for some platforms.

''[[Play (U.S. magazine)|Play]]'' awarded it 9 out of 10,<ref name="playmagrev">{{cite web|url=http://playmagazine.com/index.php?fuseaction=SiteMain.Content&contentid=1362 |title=Review – ''Mirror's Edge''|publisher=[[Play (US magazine)|Playmagazine.com]]|last=Halverson|first=Dave |date=November 10, 2008 |accessdate=December 11, 2008}}</ref> while [[GameTrailers|GameTrailers.com]] gave it 8.3 out of 10.<ref name="GameTrailersrev">{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/player/42568.html |title=GameTrailers.com – ''Mirror's Edge'' – Review |publisher=GameTrailers |accessdate=November 11, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201024331/http://www.gametrailers.com/player/42568.html |archivedate=December 1, 2008 }}</ref> ''[[Computer and Video Games]]'' was also positive, calling it "A brilliant and unique experience, even if the small shooting parts aren't quite up to scratch."<ref name="cvgrev"/> [[IGN]] awarded the game 8.3 out of 10, calling it a "thrilling and stylish venture", but "the first chapter of a franchise that's still finding its feet."<ref name=IGNps3>{{cite web|url=http://ps3.ign.com/articles/928/928824p1.html|title=''Mirror's Edge'' UK Review|last=Robinson|publisher=IGN|first=Martin|date= November 11, 2008}}</ref> [[GameSpot]] praised the immersive gameplay environments, but criticised the inconsistency of gameplay speed.<ref name="GameSpot review"/> Ian Bogost of [[Gamasutra]] commended the game for being unconventional, calling it "a shooter that makes you hate to shoot".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3890/persuasive_games_windows_and_.php?page=1|title=Features – Persuasive Games: Windows and ''Mirror's Edge''|date=December 3, 2008|last=Bogost|first=Ian|accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref>

==Expansions and sequels== [[File:MEDLC.png|thumb|alt=Floating, interconnected yellow and white blocks are seen from below. The sun shines in the left hand side of a deep blue sky|The time-trial maps feature a "more abstract aesthetic" than the main game.]]
On December 4, 2008, EA announced the creation of seven all-new time trial maps for ''Mirror's Edge'', slated for release in January 2009. According to Owen O'Brien, Senior Producer for DICE, “The freedom of movement and control in first person has been the most popular aspect of ''Mirror's Edge'' so we decided to distill these down to their purest form for this map pack... We deliberately chose a more abstract [[Aesthetics|aesthetic]] that is still within our distinctive art style and then focused on flow and gameplay to create an experience and challenge very different from the main game.”<ref>{{cite web|work=Kotaku|accessdate=February 2, 2010|date= December 4, 2008|url=http://kotaku.com/5101853/mirrors-edge-getting-time-trial-map-pack-in-january|last=Fahey|first=Mike|title=''Mirror's Edge'' Getting Time Trial Map Pack In January}}</ref> In January 2009, the release date was specified as January 29.<ref name="Kotaku-mirrorsedgedated">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5130284/mirrors-edge-dlc-dated|title=''Mirror's Edge'' DLC Dated|last=Fahey|first=Mike|date=January 13, 2009|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=January 13, 2009}}</ref> The release was delayed until February 19, 2009, when the "''Time Trial Map Pack''" was made available as downloadable content for the Xbox 360, PlayStation 3 and PC.<ref name="1up-mirrorsedge dlc">{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3172885 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226042224/http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3172885 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 26, 2009 |title=''Mirror's Edge'' DLC Available Now |last=Quillen |first=Dustin |date=February 2, 2009 |publisher=1UP.com |accessdate=February 19, 2009 }}</ref> An eighth map is available exclusively for the PlayStation 3 version of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.playstation.com/games-media/news/articles/detail/item134747/Exclusive-Mirrors-Edge-content-coming-your-way/|title=Exclusive Mirror's Edge Content Coming Your Way|work=Playstation.com|date=September 12, 2008|accessdate=February 2, 2010}}</ref>
A [[Side-scrolling video game|side-scrolling]] [[browser game]] interpretation of ''Mirror's Edge'' titled ''Mirror's Edge 2D'' was released by Electronic Arts in conjunction with independent developer Borne Games. The game is similar to and uses the modified engine of Borne's popular game ''[[Fancy Pants Adventures]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bornegames.com/2008/11/mirrors-edge-2d/|title=''Mirror's Edge 2D'' Beta |date=November 11, 2008|publisher=Borne Games|accessdate=December 4, 2008}}</ref> A one-level beta was released on November 11, 2008, with an expanded three-level beta released on February 24, 2009. The developer's site states that "the full ''Mirror's Edge 2D'' has been released, but we're still in beta."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bornegames.com/games/mirrors-edge-beta/ |title=ME 2D |publisher=Borne Games |accessdate=October 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928002116/http://www.bornegames.com/games/mirrors-edge-beta/ |archivedate=September 28, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
A version of ''Mirror's Edge'' for the [[iPhone]] and [[iPod Touch]] was announced on December 2, 2009. It is a [[side-scrolling game]] with 3D graphics, featuring 14 levels and dynamic camera angles, and was scheduled for release in January 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author=Arn|url=http://toucharcade.com/2009/12/02/eas-mirrors-edge-coming-to-iphone/|title=EA's ''Mirror's Edge'' Coming to iPhone|work=touchArcade|date=December 2, 2009|accessdate=February 3, 2010}}</ref><ref name=iphonekotaku>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5416905/mirrors-edge-running-straight-to-the-iphone|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|title=''Mirror's Edge'' Running Straight to the iPhone|work=Kotaku|date=December 2, 2009|accessdate=January 24, 2010}}</ref> It was then later revealed that the iPhone and iPod Touch versions were pushed back to an April release. EA Mobile released ''Mirror's Edge'' for iPhone and iPod touch on September 1, 2010. An [[iPad]] version was released on April 1, 2010. '''Online credentials for learning''' are [[digital credential]]s that are offered in place of traditional paper [[credential]]s for a skill or educational achievement. They are directly linked to the accelerated development of internet communication technologies, the development of [[digital badge]]s, [[electronic passport]]s and [[massive open online course]]s (MOOCs).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002428/242887e.pdf|title=Level-setting and recognition of learning outcomes: The use of level descriptors in the twenty-first century|last=Keevy|first=James|last2=Chakroun|first2=Borhene|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2015|isbn=978-92-3-100138-3|location=|pages=129–131}}</ref>
== History == Online credentials have their origin in the concept of [[open educational resources]] (OER), which was invented during the Forum on Open Courseware for Higher Education in Developing Countries held in 2002 at [[UNESCO]].<ref>Butcher, N. 2011. ''A Basic Guide to Open Educational Resources''. Vancouver, BC, Commonwealth of Learning, and Paris, UNESCO. </ref> Over the next decade the OER concept gained significant traction, and this was confirmed by the World Open Educational Resources (OER) Congress organized by UNESCO in 2012. One of the outcomes of the congress was to encourage the open licensing of educational materials produced with public funds. [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons licensing]] provides the necessary standardization for copyright permissions, with a strong emphasis on the shift towards sharing and [[Open content|open licensing]].<ref name=":0" />
== Test-based credentials == Test-based credentials have gained popularity both in the online market, and in programming and highly technical tasks. These credentials are earned by taking multiple-choice or project-based tests in various skill areas.<ref name=":0" />
== Online badges == Badges allow individuals to demonstrate job skills, educational accomplishments, online course completion or just about anything else that a badge creator decides. The concept is still quite flexible and undefined. Badges support capturing and translating learning across contexts; encouraging and motivating participation and learning outcomes; and formalizing and enhancing existing social aspects of [[Informal learning|informal]] and interest-driven learning.<ref>Mozilla Foundation and Peer 2 Peer University. 2012. Open badges for lifelong learning. Exploring an open badge ecosystem to support skill development and lifelong learning for real results such as jobs and advancement. Developed in collaboration with the MacArthur Foundation. Working document. </ref><ref name=":0" />
In Europe, since 2000, the work of the [[European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training|CEDEFOP]]<ref>Bjornavold, J. 2001. Making learning visible: identi cation, assessment and recognition of non-formal learning. ''European Journal of Vocational Training'', Vol. 22, pp. 24–32.</ref><ref name=":1">CEDEFOP. 2009. ''European Guidelines for Validating Non-Formal and Informal Learning''. Luxembourg, CEDEFOP. </ref><ref>CEDEFOP. 2014. ''Use of Validation by Enterprises for Human Resources and Career Development Purposes''. Luxembourg, CEDEFOP. </ref> and the adoption in 2009 of the European Guidelines for Validating Non-formal and Informal Learning<ref name=":1" /> have supported the development of policies and programmes periodically monitored through the European inventory on validation of [[Nonformal learning|non-formal]] and informal learning.<ref name=":0" />
Online or digital badges are not dissimilar to the concept of the [[Europass|Europass CV]]. With open badges the process is more decentralized and removed from the traditional quality assurance bodies:<ref name=":0" /><ref>Mozilla website www.openbadges.org, accessed 19 April 2014. </ref><ref name=":0" /> A criticism of open badges, such as those developed by [[Mozilla]], is that they lack a credible quality assurance component. On the positive side, open badges are free and allow for the inclusion of various forms of learning, including non-formal and informal learning.<ref name=":0" />
== Online certificates == Among alternative credentials, online certificates currently command the highest value, and are nearly comparable to a traditional degree. Earning an online certificate from an [[online college]], a company or an industry-specific organization is typically much more involved than for the other credentials. The certificates are often connected to specific job functions. Many of these certificates have been created by companies such as [[Cisco Systems|Cisco]], [[IBM]] or [[Microsoft]] to meet their own needs or the needs of their customers.<ref name=":0" />
== Future developments == Future challenges for the concept that have been identified include the way issuing and earning process for the badges is quality-assured; the centralization (or not) of the badge-issuing process and the legitimacy of any organization that takes charge of it; the way badge issuers are using the open standard to ensure that the learners stay in control and badges remain interoperable; and the way badges will be used and recognized by education institutions, enterprises and individuals.<ref name=":0" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox Journal | title = Oxford Literary Review | cover = | discipline = [[Literature]] | website = http://www.eupjournals.com/journal/olr | link1 = | link1-name = | publisher = [[Edinburgh University Press]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | abbreviation = Oxf. Lit. Rev. | history = | frequency = Twice-yearly | ISSN = 0305-1498 | eISSN = | Jstor = | OCLC = | LCCN = }} '''''Oxford Literary Review''''' is an [[academic journal]] of literary theory. The journal was founded in the late 1970s by Ian McLeod, Ann Wordsworth and [[Robert J. C. Young]], and publishes articles on the history and development of [[Deconstruction|deconstructive]] thinking in intellectual, cultural and political life. ''Oxford Literary Review'' has published new work by [[Jacques Derrida]], [[Maurice Blanchot]], [[Roland Barthes]], [[Michel Foucault]], [[Philippe Lacoue-Labarthe]], [[Jean-Luc Nancy]], and [[Hélène Cixous]], and continues to publish new work in the tradition and spirit of deconstruction.
The journal was originally published termly (i.e. three times a year), then bi-annually, though for some years it appeared as a "double issue" as an annual publication. The ''Oxford Literary Review'' is now published twice yearly by [[Edinburgh University Press]] in July and December. Special issues on specific themes alternate with general issues which include articles from varied intellectual disciplines on issues and writers belonging to or engaging with the work of deconstructive thinking (such as [[Martin Heidegger]], [[Maurice Blanchot]], [[Emmanuel Levinas]], and [[Luce Irigaray]]).
== Editors == * [[Geoffrey Bennington]], [[Emory University]] * [[Timothy Clark (literary critic)|Timothy Clark]], [[University of Durham]] * [[Peggy Kamuf]], [[University of Southern California]] * [[Michael Naas]], [[De Paul University]], Chicago * [[Nicholas Royle]], [[University of Sussex]] * [[Sarah Wood]], [[University of Kent]]
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.eupjournals.com/journal/olr}}

[[File:Prairie State Achievement Examination logo.png|thumb|250px|PSAE logo]] The '''Prairie State Achievement Examination''' ('''PSAE''') was a two-day [[standardized test]] taken by all [[High school (North America)|High School]] [[Eleventh grade|Juniors]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Illinois]]. On the first day, students take the [[ACT (examination)|ACT]], and on the second day, a [[WorkKeys]] examination and [[Illinois State Board of Education]]-developed science examination.<ref name=BOEmemo>{{cite web|url=http://www.isbe.state.il.us/assessment/pdfs/psae_grad_guid_memo.pdf |title=Memorandum:2006-07 Guidance – Graduation and the Prairie State Achievement Examination |accessdate=April 20, 2007 |author=Becky McCabe, Division Administrator, Student Assessment Division |date=August 21, 2006 |format=PDF |publisher=[[Illinois State Board of Education]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060213040300/http://www.isbe.state.il.us/assessment/pdfs/psae_grad_guid_memo.pdf |archivedate=February 13, 2006 }}</ref> The test is no longer administered in Illinois schools; however, it was required for all Illinois High School Students from 2001-2014.<ref name=PSAEreport>{{cite web |url=http://ccsr.uchicago.edu/publications/psae_report.pdf |title=Understanding the Prairie State Achievement Exam |accessdate=April 20, 2007 |author=Stephen M. Ponisciak |date=September 2005 |format=PDF |publisher=[[University of Chicago]]}}</ref>
==Areas of Assessment== The PSAE attempted to assess students on the following areas:<ref name=BOEoverview>{{cite web |url=http://www.isbe.state.il.us/assessment/psae.htm |title=Prairie State Achievement Examination (PSAE) |accessdate=April 20, 2007 |publisher=[[Illinois State Board of Education]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427072148/http://www.isbe.state.il.us/assessment/psae.htm |archivedate=April 27, 2007 |df= }}</ref> *Math *Reading *Science *Writing
==Exemptions== A student was required to take the PSAE to achieve a [[high school diploma]], unless he or she met one of the following requirements:<ref name=BOEmemo /> *The student’s [[Individualized Education Program]] is incompatible with the PSAE, and the test cannot be modified to comply. In this case, the student takes the [[Illinois Alternate Assessment]] instead. *The student is not proficient in [[English language|English]]. In this case the student takes the [[Illinois Measure of Annual Growth in English]] instead. *The student is enrolled in an alternative Education program, including an adult education program, or high school equivalency certificates.
==References== <references />
==Read more== * [[ACT (test)|ACT]] * [[WorkKeys]]

revision.text: {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2012}} {{multiple issues|{{example farm|date=January 2017}} {{original research|date=April 2008}}}} A '''satiric misspelling''' is an intentional misspelling of a word, phrase or name for a [[rhetoric]]al purpose. This is often done by replacing a letter with another letter (for example, ''[[k]]'' replacing ''[[c]]''), or symbol (for example, ''[[$]]'' replacing ''[[s]]'', ''[[@]]'' replacing ''[[a]]'', or ''[[¢]]'' replacing ''c''). Satiric misspelling is found particularly in [[Internet slang|informal writing on the Internet]], but can also be found in some serious political writing that opposes the [[status quo]]. == ''K'' replacing ''c'' == Replacing the letter ''c'' with ''k'' in the first letter of a word came into use by the [[Ku Klux Klan]] during its early years in the mid-to-late 19th century. The concept is continued today within the group. [[File:Barc okupa.jpg|thumb|Barcelona squat and anarchist centre, labelled "OKUPA Y RESISTE"]] In the 1960s and early 1970s in the [[United States]], [[left-wing politics|leftists]], particularly the [[Yippies]], sometimes used ''[[Amerika (disambiguation)|Amerika]]'' rather than ''America'' in referring to the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.schwarzreport.org/Newsletters/1969/november15,69.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123223245/http://www.schwarzreport.org/Newsletters/1969/november15%2C69.htm |title=CACC NEWSLETTER |archivedate=January 23, 2008 |work=schwarzreport.org |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://hippy.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=81|title=A Call to Arms (1969?) - Hippy Land, Home of the Hippies|work=hippy.com}}{{cite web|url=http://riseup.net/sds/graphics.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050726012713/http://riseup.net/sds/graphics.htm |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|archivedate=July 26, 2005 |work=riseup.net}}http://www2.lib.virginia.edu/exhibits/sixties/radical.html{{cite web|url=http://www1.american.edu/bgriff/H207web/sixties/rubinchildofAmerika.htm|title=Jerry Rubin: Self-Portrait of a Child of "Amerika," 1970|work=american.edu}} It is still used as a political statement today.{{cite web|url=http://www.jasonalexandercruz.com/|title=Nachrichten aus der Musik- und Entertainmentbranche - Jasonalexandercruz.com|work=jasonalexandercruz.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/guinnessgurl/sets/148438/|title=political|work=Flickr}} It is likely that this was originally an allusion to the [[German language|German]] spelling of the word, and intended to be suggestive of [[Nazism]], a hypothesis that the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' supports. In broader usage, the replacement of the letter ''c'' with ''k'' denotes general political skepticism about the topic at hand and is intended to discredit or debase the term in which the replacement occurs.{{cite web|title=LeSaint's Sloth Cave|url=http://www.le-saint.com/wear.html|accessdate=29 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929121925/http://www.le-saint.com/wear.html |archivedate=September 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} A similar usage in [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Catalan Language|Catalan]] and [[Portuguese Language|Portuguese]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} is to write ''okupa'' rather than ''ocupa'' (often on a building or area occupied by [[squatter]]s,{{cite web|url=http://comunidades.calle22.com/comunidades/397/com397con2.asp |title=comunidades.calle22.com - TODOS SOMOS OKUPAS |accessdate=2004-10-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611121504/http://comunidades.calle22.com/comunidades/397/com397con2.asp |archivedate=June 11, 2008 |df= }} referring to the name adopted by ''okupación'' activist groups), which is particularly remarkable because the letter "k" is not part of the Spanish, Portuguese or Italian alphabets. It stems from a combination of English borrow words with k in them to those languages, and [[Anarchism in Spain|Spanish anarchist]] and [[Punk rock|punk]] movements which used "k" to signal rebellion.{{cite web|last=Rodríguez González|first=Félix|year=2006|title=Medios de comunicación y contracultura juvenil|work=Círculo|volume=25:5–30|url=http://www.ucm.es/info/circulo/no25/rodriguez.pdf|format=PDF}} Replacing "c" with "k" was at the centre of a [[Monty Python]] joke from the Travel Agent sketch. [[Eric Idle]] has an affliction that makes him pronounce the letter C as a B, as in "bolour" instead of "colour." [[Michael Palin]] asks him if he can say the letter K? Idle replies that he can, and Palin suggests that he spell words with a K instead of C. Idle replies, "what, spell bolour with a K? Kolour. Oh! I never thought of that before! What a silly [[Cunt#Comedy|bunt]]!"{{cite web|title=Transcript|url=http://web.mit.edu/humor/Special/Monty.Python/travel.agency|work=Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Index of Humor|accessdate=29 May 2015}} The video game franchise [[Mortal Kombat]] is another example of this trend. ===''KKK'' replacing ''c'' or ''k''=== A common satiric usage of the letters ''KKK'' is the spelling of ''America'' as ''Amerikkka'', alluding to the [[Ku Klux Klan]], drawing to a perceived notion of an underlying or inherent [[Racism in the United States|racism]] in American society. The earliest known usage of ''Amerikkka'' recorded in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' is in 1970, in a journal called ''Black World''. Presumably, this was an extrapolation from the then already widespread ''Amerika''.{{Clarify|date=December 2014}}{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} The spelling ''Amerikkka'' came into greater use after the 1990 release of the [[gangsta rap]] album ''[[AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted]]'' by [[Ice Cube]], also used by rapper [[Spice 1]] for his album ''[[AmeriKKKa's Nightmare]]'' and by [[shock rock]] band [[Undercover Slut]] for their album ''Amerikkka Macht Frei''.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} The letters ''KKK'' have been inserted into several other words and names, to indicate similar perceived racism, oppression or corruption. Examples include: * ''Republikkkan'' ([[Republican Party (United States)|U.S. Republican Party]]){{cite web|url=http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |title=The Blackstripe - Stolen 2000 Election |accessdate=2004-10-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060225154916/http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |archivedate=February 25, 2006 |df= }} * ''Demokkkrat'' ([[Democratic Party (United States)|U.S. Democratic Party]]){{cite web|url=http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |title=The Blackstripe - Stolen 2000 Election |accessdate=2004-10-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060225154916/http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |archivedate=February 25, 2006 |df= }} * ''KKKapitalism'' ([[capitalism]]){{cite web|url=http://home4.inet.tele.dk/lepan/lene/indiana/mscritical.htm |title=From Critical Reflections to Forward Progression |accessdate=2005-11-04 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104162056/http://home4.inet.tele.dk/lepan/lene/indiana/mscritical.htm |archivedate=November 4, 2005 |df=mdy }} * ''KKKommunism'' ([[communism]]){{cite web|url=http://www.therightperspective.org/2008/08/22/kommunism-is-aprtheid/|title=Kommunism is Apartheid!|author=frankvonqueens|date=2008-08-22|accessdate=2012-11-28|work=The Right Perspective|publisher=[[Peter Goodman]]}} * ''David DuKKKe'' ([[David Duke]]), former [[Grand Wizard]] of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], candidate for [[United States Senate]], candidate for [[Governor of Louisiana]], and now [[YouTube]] and web [[antisemitic conspiracy theory|antisemitic conspiracy theorist]]{{cite book|last1=Barkun|first1=Michael|title=Religion and the Racist Right: The Origins of the Christian Identity Movement|date=1997|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=9780807846384|page=315|edition=illustrated, revised|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bdGSbDaCQVsC&pg=PA315|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ==Currency signs== The [[US dollar|dollar]] sign ($) can be inserted in the place of the letter ''S'', the [[euro]] sign (€) in place of ''[[e]]'', the [[Japanese yen|yen]] (¥) sign in place of ''[[Y]]'', the [[South Korean won|won]] (₩) sign in place of ''[[W]]'', or the [[pound sterling|pound]] (£) sign in place of ''[[L]],'' or the [[Indian rupee|rupee]] sign (₹) in place of ''R'' to indicate [[plutocracy]], [[greed (emotion)|greed]], [[political corruption|corruption]], or the perceived immoral, unethical, or pathological accumulation of [[money]]. For example: * ''App£e'' (for [[Apple Inc.]]);{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} see also [[Criticism of Apple Inc.]]. * ''Autism $peaks'' (for [[Autism Speaks]]),{{cite web|last1=Cincotta |first1=Frank |last2=Binns |first2=Rebecca |title=Autism $peaks U are Clueless |url=http://arisespringfield.org/autism-peaks-u-are-clueless/ |work=Arise for Social Justice |accessdate=29 May 2015 |date=8 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529174249/http://arisespringfield.org/autism-peaks-u-are-clueless/ |archivedate=May 29, 2015 }} often used on blogging sites such as [[Tumblr]].{{cite web|title=#autism $peaks on Tumblr|url=https://www.tumblr.com/tagged/autism-$peaks|publisher=Tumblr|accessdate=29 May 2015}} * ''Bu$h'' (for [[George W. Bush]], [[George Herbert Walker Bush]], or any member of the [[Bush family]]){{cite web|url=https://www.ledevoir.com/non-classe/41033/stoppez-bu-h |title=«Stoppez Bu$h |publisher=Le Devoir |date=}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.democrats.com/view.cfm?id=8158 |title=Caught in the Crossfire: What Will Bu$h Do About Corporate Corruption? |publisher=Archive.democrats.com |date=June 28, 2002 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2003/11/281262.html |title=UK Indymedia - Stop Bu$h - National Demonstration - Thursday 20th |publisher=Indymedia.org.uk |date=November 20, 2003 }} * Congre$$ (for [[United States Congress]]){{citation needed|date=August 2014}}. * ''Co$'' or ''$cientology'' (for the [[Church of Scientology]]){{cite web|url=http://www.xenu.org/cartoon/ |title=The $cientology Cartoon Page |accessdate=2005-02-24 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302124138/http://www.xenu.org/cartoon/ |archivedate=March 2, 2007 |df= }} * ''Di$ney'' and ''Di$neyland''{{cite web|url=http://www.bakersfield.com/news/opinion/2014/12/17/joe-mathews-di-neyland-ought-to-give-kids-a-break.html|title=JOE MATHEWS: Di$neyland ought to give kids a break|author=By|work=The Bakersfield Californian}} See [[Criticism of The Walt Disney Company]] and [[Disneyland#Tickets]] * ''E$$o'' (for [[Esso]]): Used by the UK-based [[Stop Esso campaign]] encouraging people to [[boycott]] Esso, in protest against Esso's opposition to the [[Kyoto Protocol]].{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/climate/interview-with-a-stop-esso-activist|title=Interview with a Stop Esso activist|work=[[Greenpeace]]|date=November 29, 2001|accessdate=December 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108231651/http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/climate/interview-with-a-stop-esso-activist|archivedate=January 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}} * ''Hill$ong'' (for [[Hillsong Church]]): Used by people against the Hillsong Church to state that they exist only to take offerings to be used for workers' luxury rather than Christian-like charitable uses.{{cite web|url=http://www.cwm.org.au/3/24-52/271-9|title=Christian Witness Ministries - Why I left Hill$ong Brisbane Campus|author=Lance Goodall|work=cwm.org.au}}{{better source|reason=The source uses the phrase in question but doesn't comment on it or explain the joke. The material it is cited for is original research.|date=July 2015}} * "[[Green Chri$tma$]]", a song by [[Stan Freberg]], satirizing [[Commercialization of Christmas]] * ''I$rael'', among those who perceive [[Israel]] as overtly [[Israel-United States relations|dependant on the United States]],{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} and sometimes also as a manifestation of the anti-Semitic belief that Jews are [[Antisemitic canard#Accusations of usury and profiteering|overtly obsessed]] with money and/or [[Antisemitic canard#Accusations of controlling the world financial system|control the financial markets]].{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} * [[Kesha|Ke$ha]]: Pop music artist. She adopted the dollar sign in her name while struggling to get by as an ironic gesture.{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/K/Kesha/2010/01/19/12529526-qmi.html |title=View Single Post - Pop sensation Ke$ha gutsy, fearless |publisher=jam.canoe.ca |date=January 19, 2010 }} * ''kla$$'' (for [[class conflict|class]]): Used to draw attention to the belief that American citizens are widely and unfairly ranked solely on terms of their material wealth * ''[[Mase|Ma$e]]'': Rapper who formerly used to stylize his stage name with a dollar sign in place of an S. * ''McDonald'$'' * ''Micro$oft'', ''M$'', ''M$FT'' (for [[Microsoft]]), as well as ''Micro$oft Windoze'' for [[Microsoft Windows]];{{cite web|url=http://www.madore.org/~david/computers/antims.html |title=A plea against Micro$oft |publisher=madore.org |author=David Madore |date= }} see also [[Criticism of Microsoft]] * ''Orac£e'' (for [[Oracle Corporation]]){{citation needed|date=August 2014}} * ''Ro£€x or'' ₹''o£€x'' (for [[Rolex]]){{citation needed|date=August 2014}} * ''Ru$$ia'' (for [[Russia]]){{cite web|url=http://www.zaimka.ru/today/olekh6.shtml |title=Olekh G. L. Novosibirsk Oblast: Problems of Globalization and Regionalization. На пороге будущего… "Сибирская Заимка" —история Сибири в научных публикациях |publisher=Zaimka.ru |date= }} * ''$ky'' (for [[Sky plc]]), used by those who perceive the British pay-TV broadcaster as an overt Americanising force. * ''$ocialism'' or ''$ociali$m'' (for [[Socialism]]): Critics{{who|date=August 2014}} have pointed out that the idea of socialism has been exploited for profit, by politicians, corporations and artists, in particular as a criticism of [[Michael Moore]].[http://www.regainingsteam.com/blog/crony55.html ]{{dead link|date=August 2014}}[http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/20010/09/michael_a_success_story.html ]{{dead link|date=August 2012}} * ''$ony'' (for [[Sony]]){{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * ''Uncle $am'' (for [[Uncle Sam]]){{cite web|url=http://www.countryjoe.com/fixins.htm |title=Country Joe McDonald, All the Fixin's |publisher=Countryjoe.com |date= }} * ''United $tates'', ''United $tate$'', ''U$'', ''U$A'' (for the [[United States]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.infoshop.org/gulag/stories.php?story=03%2F02%2F14%2F9738882 |title=American Gulag - Dismantle the Prison-Industrial Complex |accessdate=2017-05-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041223062105/http://www.infoshop.org/gulag/stories.php?story=03%2F02%2F14%2F9738882 |archivedate=December 23, 2004 |df= }} * ''₩a$hington'' (for [[Washington, D.C.]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.etext.org/Politics/MIM/mn/html/mn261.html |title=MIM Notes - Bush signs $190 billion farm bill opposing 'free trade' |accessdate=2004-10-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123081354/http://www.etext.org/Politics/MIM/mn/html/mn261.html |archivedate=January 23, 2008 |df= }} * ''₩indo₩$'' (for [[Microsoft Windows]]){{cite web|url=http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/showpost.php?p=4108262 |title=View Single Post - The All New Linux vs Windows MegaSuperThread |publisher=LinuxQuestions.org |date=September 24, 2010 }} == @ replacing A, at or O== Since at least 1980, people have used the "at sign" ("[[@]]") as a representation of the [[Anarchy a|circled letter A]]. This has been extended to substituting it for the letter "A" as in the [[Crass]] [[fanzine]] ''Toxic Gr@fity''.{{cite web|url=http://www.southern.com/southern/label/CRC/1980.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206073619/http://www.southern.com/southern/label/CRC/1980.html|archivedate=December 6, 2010|deadurl=yes|title=Crass Discography}} In Spanish, it became informally common (but not accepted by the [[Real Academia Espanola|RAE]], due to @ being a symbol and not a letter) to use @ in place of "o/a" to denote both genders. For example, "señorit@" can be used to mean "señorita and/or señorito" instead of using "señorita/o." ==Word-in-word== Occasionally a word written in its orthodox spelling is altered with internal capital letters, hyphens, italics, or other devices so as to highlight a fortuitous pun. Some examples: * After the controversial [[U.S. presidential election, 2000|2000 U.S. Presidential elections]], the alleged improprieties of the election prompted the use of such titles as "pResident" and "(p)resident"{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20010326&s=contest |archive-url=https://archive.is/20060530225708/http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20010326&s=contest |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 30, 2006 |title=Name the President! |date=March 18, 2006 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gainesvillehumanists.org/alerts.htm |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 14, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041013030443/http://www.gainesvillehumanists.org/alerts.htm |archivedate=October 13, 2004 |df= }} for [[George W. Bush]]. The same effects were also used for [[Bill Clinton]] during and after Clinton's impeachment hearings. These devices were intended to suggest that the president was merely the ''resident'' of the [[White House]] rather than the legitimate leader. * Similarly, the controversial [[United States]] law, the ''[[USA PATRIOT Act]]'', is sometimes called the "patRiot Act", "(pat)Riot Act", "PAT Riot Act", "PAT RIOT Act", or "You Sap At Riot Act"{{cite web|url=http://www.stallman.org/pat-riot-act.html |title=PAT RIOT Act - Richard Stallman |publisher=Stallman.org |date= }}{{cite web|url=http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=115660&cid=9794643 |title=Slashdot Comments | British Columbia Acts Against Patriot Act |publisher=Yro.slashdot.org |date=July 25, 2004 }} by its opponents. * Feminist theologian [[Mary Daly]] has used a [[slash (punctuation)|slash]] to make a point about [[patriarchy]]: "gyn/ecology", "stag/nation", "the/rapist".[http://www.salon.com/it/feature/1999/03/17feature.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050128070855/http://www.salon.com/it/feature/1999/03/17feature.html |date=January 28, 2005 }} * In French, where ''con'' is an insulting word meaning "moron", the word ''conservateur'' (conservative) has been written "con-servateur",{{cite web|url=http://membres.lycos.fr/prince2/Elections/J30.HTM |title=Elections Québec '98 |date=June 11, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611134857/http://membres.lycos.fr/prince2/Elections/J30.HTM |archivedate=June 11, 2008 }} "con… servateur",{{cite web|url=http://www.chantiers.org/cri.htm |title=cri |publisher=Chantiers.org |date= }} or "con(servateur)".{{cite web|url=http://www.france-mail-forum.de/fmf31/pol/31ruscio.htm |title=France-Mail-Forum Nr. 31: Politique et histoire |date=June 11, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611123723/http://www.france-mail-forum.de/fmf31/pol/31ruscio.htm |archivedate=June 11, 2008 }} The American English term ''neo-con'', an abbreviation of ''[[Neoconservatism|neo-conservative]]'', becomes a convenient pun when used in French.{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&objet_id=893321 |title=Les deux vies de " Wolfie ", le " néo-con " au " coeur qui saigne |publisher=LeMonde.fr |date= }} In English, the first syllable of ''con''servative can be emphasized to suggest a [[Confidence trick|con artist]].{{cite web|author=Jane Kleeb |url=http://www.boldnebraska.org/con-servative-bait-and-switch |title="Con"servative Bait and Switch |publisher=Boldnebraska.org |date=July 2, 2010 |accessdate=2012-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402114344/http://www.boldnebraska.org/con-servative-bait-and-switch |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df=mdy }} * The British political satire magazine ''[[Private Eye]]'' has a long-standing theme of insulting the law firm [[Carter-Ruck]] by replacing the R with an F to read Carter-Fuck. The law firm once requested that Private Eye cease spelling its name like that; the magazine then started spelling it "Farter-Fuck".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1450022/Peter-Carter-Ruck.html|title=Peter Carter-Ruck|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=22 December 2003|accessdate=27 January 2015}} Likewise, ''Private Eye'' often refers to ''[[The Guardian]]'' as ''[[The Grauniad]]'',{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2000/dec/16/society|title=Surely shome mishtake?|work=The Guardian|date=16 December 2000| location=London|last=Sherrin|first=Ned|authorlink=Ned Sherrin}} due to the newspaper's early reputation for [[typographical errors]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_oO5fWi6dikC&pg=PA26 |pages=26–27 |title=Porcupine, Picayune, & Post: how newspapers get their names |first=Jim|last=Bernhard|publisher=University of Missouri Press|year=2007|isbn=0-8262-1748-6|accessdate=11 August 2013}} * Netizens often called [[Bong Revilla|Sen. Ramon "Bong" Revilla Jr.]] as "''MandaramBONG''" (Filipino word for [[plunder]]er) to highlight allegations that he pocketed pork barrel funds through the use of fake non-government organizations.{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/01/20/14/mandarambong-netizens-twit-revilla-speech |title='MandaramBong': Netizens twit Revilla speech |work=ABS-CBN News |date=2014-01-20}} == Other significant respellings == {{See also|Misnomer}} Along the same lines, intentional misspellings can be used to promote a specific negative attribute, real or perceived, of a product or service. This is especially effective if the misspelling is done by replacing part of the word with another that has identical phonetic qualities. Some [[toponyms|place names]] are also spelled differently in order to emphasize some political view. For instance, ''Brasil'' (the Portuguese spelling of "Brazil"), is sometimes misconstrued as a typo for ''Brazil'' in English texts.{{cite web |url=http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definition/brasil |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-09-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190200/http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definition/brasil |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Alternatively, the English spelling ''Brazil'' is used in Portuguese pieces of text as a way to denote [[anti-Americanism]] or [[Anti-globalization|anti-globalization sentiment]]. Journalists may make a politicized editorial decision by choosing to differentially retain (or even create) misspellings, mispronunciations, ungrammaticisms, dialect variants, or interjections. ===Backronyms=== {{Main|Backronym}} Plays on [[acronym]]s and [[initialism]]s are also common, when the full name is spelled out but one of the component words is replaced by another. For example, [[Richard Stallman]] and other [[Free Software Foundation]] executives often refer to [[digital rights management]] as "digital '''restrictions''' management",[[Digital rights management#Opposition to DRM]] a reference to the tendency for DRM to stifle the end user's ability to reshare music or write CDs more than a certain number of times. Likewise, the [[National Security Agency]] is often referred to as the "National '''Surveillance''' Agency"{{cite web|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/2615652243001/national-surveillance-agency-audit-reveals-nsa-violations|title=National 'Surveillance' Agency? Audit reveals NSA violations|work=Fox News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.idigitaltimes.com/articles/18295/20130614/nsa-prism-apple-google-microsoft-glass-xbox.htm |title=National Surveillance Agency: Looking At Google Glass, Xbox One Through The NSA's Prism [OPINION] |date=June 14, 2013 |work=iDigitalTimes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928032348/http://www.idigitaltimes.com/articles/18295/20130614/nsa-prism-apple-google-microsoft-glass-xbox.htm |archivedate=September 28, 2013 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://n4g.com/news/1282615/national-surveillance-agency-looking-at-google-glass-xbox-one-through-the-nsas-prism|title=National Surveillance Agency: Looking At Google Glass, Xbox One Through The NSA's Prism|work=n4g.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=40803 |title=National Surveillance Agency program is still ongoing |author=Catholic Online |work=catholic.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225144748/http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=40803 |archivedate=December 25, 2013 |df=mdy }} and sometimes "[[Nazism|National Socialist]] Agency"http://quartermoonsaloon.com/forum/archive/index.php/t-21247.htmlhttp://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/national_socialist_agency_national_security_agency_or_nsa_nickname by opponents of its [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] program, who view it as dystopian encroachment on personal privacy. == See also == * [[Eye dialect]] * [[Herstory]] * [[Leet]] * [[Play on words]] * [[Pun]] * [[Sensational spelling]] * [[Womyn]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040925080243/http://home4.inet.tele.dk/lepan/lene/indiana/jun00.htm#Mangwiro On de spelling and use of various words] by Mangwiro A.
